headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. My name is Tanisha and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the first quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Mr. Kevin Coleman, you may begin your
componenttext: Good morning, everyone. My name is Tanisha and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the first quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Mr. Kevin Coleman, you may begin your call.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tanisha. Good morning. Welcome to AMETEK's First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Joining me this morning are Frank Hermance, Chairman and CEO; Bob Mandos, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Dave Zapico, Executive Vice P
componenttext:
Thank you, Tanisha. Good morning. Welcome to AMETEK's First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Joining me this morning are Frank Hermance, Chairman and CEO; Bob Mandos, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Dave Zapico, Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer.
AMETEK's first quarter results were released earlier this morning. These results are available electronically on market systems and on our website at the Investor Relations section of ametek.com. The call is also webcast and can be accessed at ametek.com and streetevents.com. The call will be archived on both of those sites.
Any statements made by AMETEK during the call that are not historical in nature are to be considered forward-looking statements. As such, these statements are subject to change based on various risk factors and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ significantly from expectations.
A detailed discussion of the risks and uncertainties that may affect our future results is contained in AMETEK's filings with the SEC. AMETEK disclaims any intention or obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements.
I will also refer you to the Investor section of ametek.com for a reconciliation of any non-GAAP financial measures used during this call. We'll begin today with prepared remarks, and then we'll open it up to take questions. 
I'll turn the meeting over now to Frank.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kevin, and good morning, everyone. AMETEK delivered solid earnings in the first quarter despite a very challenging global macro environment. Overall demand across a number of our markets remains weak. In particular, we are seeing meaningful h
componenttext:
Thank you, Kevin, and good morning, everyone. 
AMETEK delivered solid earnings in the first quarter despite a very challenging global macro environment. Overall demand across a number of our markets remains weak. In particular, we are seeing meaningful headwinds within our oil and gas and metals markets.
These headwinds are larger than we anticipated when we started the year. Although these short-term headwinds are challenging, we remained confident in the long-term positioning and the growth prospects for our business. Before covering the financial highlights, please note that any references made to 2015 results will be on an adjusted basis, excluding the realignment costs in 2015. Now onto the financial results.
In the first quarter, sales declined 4% to $944.4 million. Organic sales were down 9%, acquisitions added 5% and foreign currency was a 1% headwind during the quarter.
Operating income for the first quarter declined 12% to $208.5 million and operating income margin in the quarter was 22.1% versus 24.1% in the first quarter of 2015.
Net income for the quarter was $134.2 million and diluted earnings per share of $0.57, or down 10% over last year's first quarter, meeting our Street guidance.
Operating cash flow was $152 million in the quarter, up 24% over the prior year.
Now turning to the individual operating groups. Electronic Instruments Group reported a sales decline of 4% to $569 million for the quarter, organic sales declined 8%. The acquisitions of Surface Vision Brookfield Engineering and ESP/SurgeX contributed  5% and foreign currency was a 1% headwind.
The lower sales versus prior year were driven largely by our process business which had exposure to oil and gas markets. We are seeing incremental weakness above our prior expectations in oil and gas, both in the upstream and in the mid and downstream markets.
EIGs operating income declined 12% to $141.8 million, and operating margins were 24.9% in the quarter versus 27% in last year's first quarter.
Electromechanical Group reported overall sales down 4% to $375.4 million. Organic sales were down 9%, the acquisition of Global Tubes added 6% and foreign currency was a 1% headwind.
The lower sales were driven largely by the impact in commodity prices deflation and our engineered materials and packaging business as well as from soft demand in our Floorcare & Specialty Motors business. EMGs operating income of $79.4 million was down 10% from last year's first quarter and operating margins were 21.2% in the quarter versus 22.7% in the first quarter of 2015.
I'll now provide some updates on our 4 growth strategies of Operational Excellence, Global & Market Expansion, New Product Development and Strategic Acquisitions.
Each of these strategies plays an integral role in the overall growth and success of AMETEK. We are focused on consistently executing on each of the strategies over the business cycle. However, in slow growth environments,  we increased our focus on Strategic Acquisitions and Operational Excellence initiatives, while ensuring we continue to make targeted investments in research and development in global expansion.
First, let me touch on acquisitions.
We've got a good start of the year, acquiring 2 business in the first quarter, Brookfield Engineering Laboratories and ESP/SurgeX. Combined, we deployed approximately $300 million in capital and acquired nearly $100 million in sales.
ESP/SurgeX is a leader in power protection. Their protected products operate at the plug level and monitor, project, analyze and diagnose power-related issues remotely or on-site.
In addition, their products help control power to mission-critical equipment. ESP is a great strategic fit with our existing power protection platform. It is highly complementary with our recently acquired power of our business, providing us with new opportunities for product innovation and market expansion.
The company has annual sales of approximately $40 million and is headquartered in North Carolina.
Brookfield is the global leader in viscosity measurement instrumentation for quality control applications. The company provides a complete range of discometers [ph] and rheometers as well as instrumentation for the analysis of texture and powder flow. Key applications for Brookfield's products include research, development and production of food and beverage, pharmaceutical, paint and petroleum products.
The addition of Brookfield allows AMETEK to expand our laboratory instrumentation platform into a broader range of adjacent markets and applications. They are headquartered in Middleborrough [ph] Massachusetts with additional operations in Germany and the United Kingdom, China and India and of annual sales of approximately $55 million.
The integration of both of these acquisitions is going very well. As part of our acquisition integration process, we conduct monthly integration meetings with each acquired company for at least the first 6 months following acquisition. These meetings are important drivers of the success of our acquisition strategy as they allow us to closely monitor progress on key integration activities and value drivers during the critical early stages of the integration.
Acquisitions will continue to be a key focus for us. They will continue to be the primary use of our strong cash flow and financing facilities. Our acquisition and business teams remain very active and so we are quite bullish on our opportunity to continue to deploy capital and create meaningful shareholder value.
Now turning to Operational Excellence. Our management teams and employees are doing a great job driving continued operational efficiencies and improvements through their businesses by leveraging our Operational Excellence tools.
Our Operational Excellence initiatives take on even greater importance and become more of a focus in slow growth environments. For all of 2016, we now anticipate approximately $130 million of total Operational Excellence savings, with our global sourcing and strategic impairment initiatives driving approximately $60 million of the total savings.
The total Operational Excellence savings is up from our initial estimate of $120 million as a result of the continued strong efforts of our teams.
Now moving on to new products. We're pleased with the continued success of our new product development activities. Our businesses are doing an outstanding job developing and introducing exciting new products. These new product developments are targeted at both expanding and existing markets and penetrating adjacent markets.
Despite the slow growth environment, we continue to invest meaningfully in our new product development activities. In 2016, we expect to spend approximately $210 million on RD&E, up 5% from last year.
We continue to see excellent results from these investment as our vitality index, which measures revenue from products introduced over the last 3 years, was 22% of sales in the quarter. We have a number of notable new product introductions within the quarter. The newsy post energy dispersive x-ray fluorescence spectrometer from our Spectro Analytical Instruments business  is considered a breakthrough product for performing elemental analysis. The compact, benchtop unit incorporates a number of advances that allow it to perform rapid, multielement analysis with greater accuracy and precision.
The instruments and enhancements make it suitable for demanding environmental and geological research as well as precise outline quality control in chemical and petrochemical production, food processing and pharmaceutical production.
The new extreme performance series of [indiscernible] from AMETEK delivers best-in-class airflow for harsh and demanding military aerospace and industrial environments. The new fans features shockproof, middle spec construction and are optimized for electronic cooling applications. The fans are offered with a range of features that permit their use in a variety of situations and configurations. They can be used alone are stacked with multiple fans to cool electronics, equipment racks and personnel and airborne land-based and sea born installations. 
Our Zygo business provided high-precision optics that were used in the recent detection of gravitation waves that confirmed one of the key predictions in Einstein's 1915 Theory of Relativity. The international team of scientist that collaborated on the discovery relied on advanced detectors that incorporated very high precision optical components manufactured by Zygo. The optics manufactured to some sub-nanometer tolerances are among the most precise optics ever made. I'd like to recognize the Zygo team on their
contribution to the success of this important, global, scientific project. 
Now turning to Global & Market Expansion. Global & Market Expansion continues to be an important part of our long-term growth. In the first quarter, international sales represented 33% of our total sales. We remain committed to expanding our presence and attractive higher growth regions in market segments to continued investments in our sales and service capabilities and through the expansion of our technology into a new adjacent market segments. Want to highlight one of the recent success of our adjacent market expansion initiatives. 
Our process instruments business has pioneered near infrared tunable diode laser absorption spectroscopy or TDLAS technology. This technology has been very successful for use in online process applications within natural gas processing and petrochemical production. The process instruments business is now adapting the TDLAS technology for use in online pharmaceutical processing through modifying its existing model 5100 series analyzers to provide continuous process control of pharmaceutical drawing.
The use of this technology as an online analysis tool allows manufacturers to obtain a clear picture of the drawing process in real-time. It is an economical and efficient technique for determining driver endpoint detection since it eliminates the need for pharmaceutical manufacturers to stop, analyze and restart the drying process.
The process instruments team is starting to see strong interest in this new market application for an existing technology.
Now turning to the outlook for 2016. As a result of the end-market challenges, we now anticipate overall sales for 2016 to be roughly flat versus 2015 with organic sales down low to mid-single digits on a percentage basis versus 2015. We expect earnings for 2016 to be in the range of $2.42 to $2.52 per diluted share, down 1% to 5% over last year.
Our overall second quarter 2016 sales are expected to be down low single digits versus the second quarter of 2015. We estimate our second quarter earnings to be approximately $0.58 to $0.59 per diluted share, down 8% to 9% over last year's second quarter.
In summary, while the economic environment across many of our markets remains challenging and very difficult to predict, we remain focused on executing on the factors within our control. This includes the point of capital on strategic acquisitions making growth investments in new product development and global expansion and executing on our operational excellence initiatives.
Our strong cash flow and improving operating model give us confidence that we will continue our long track record of strong performance and shareholder value creation.
Bob will now cover some of the financial details and then we'll be glad to take your questions.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Frank. As Frank noted, we had a solid first quarter. I will provide further details.In the quarter, organic selling expenses on a percentage basis were down in line with organic sales on an organic basis. General and administrative expenses w
componenttext:
Thank you, Frank. As Frank noted, we had a solid first quarter. I will provide further details.
In the quarter, organic selling expenses on a percentage basis were down in line with organic sales on an organic basis. General and administrative expenses were 1.3% of sales in the quarter, slightly above last year's first quarter level of 1.2% of sales.
The effective tax rate for the quarter was 26.7%, down from last year's first quarter rate of 28.1% and in line with our expectations. The lower tax rate in the quarter was the result of our ongoing tax planning initiatives.
For 2016, we estimate our tax rate to be approximately 28%. As we've said before, actual quarterly tax rates can differ dramatically, either positively or negatively from its full year rate.
On the balance sheet, working capital, defined as receivables plus inventories less payables, was 20.8% of sales in the first quarter. Strong working capital management remained a key priority.
Capital expenditures were $11 million for the quarter. Full year 2016 capital expenditures are expected to be approximately $70 million.
Depreciation and amortization was $40 million for the quarter. 2016 depreciation and amortization is expected to be approximately $165 million.
Our cash flow was very strong in the quarter. Operating cash flow was $152 million, up 24% over last year's first quarter. Free cash flow was $141 million, representing 105% of net income.
For the full year, we expect free cash flow to be approximately 120% of net income.
The primary use of our strong cash flow is to support our acquisition strategy. In the first quarter, we deployed $300 million for the acquisition of Brookfield and ESP/SurgeX. In addition, in the first quarter, we repurchased approximately 2.4 million shares of stock for approximately $115 million.
Total debt was $2.22 billion at March 31, up $280 million from 2015 year end. Offsetting that debt is cash and cash equivalents of $386.9 million, resulting in a net debt to capital ratio for March 31 of 35.7%.
At March 31, we had approximately $900 million of cash and existing credit facilities to fund our growth initiatives. This amount includes the incremental financing capacity provided through the amended revolving credit facility we announced on March 11. This amended facility increasing the side of our revolving credit facility from $700 million to $850 million, and extends the maturity date to March 2021, provides AMETEK with a large financing capacity and increased flexibility to support our growth initiatives.
Our highest priority is our capital deployment remains acquisitions. In summary, our business has performed well in the first quarter, despite the challenging macroeconomic conditions. We are well positioned with a strong balance sheet and cash flows to support our growth initiatives.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Brian Konigsberg of Vertical Research.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to start off maybe just more of a conceptual question. So Q1 marks this -- maybe the second or third quarter in a row where you fell short of expectations on an operational basis. Just thinking about how you're thinking when you go into the pl
componenttext: I just want to start off maybe just more of a conceptual question. So Q1 marks this -- maybe the second or third quarter in a row where you fell short of expectations on an operational basis. Just thinking about how you're thinking when you go into the planning process for guidance, what is it that changed of this becoming a lot more difficult to guide in this market? We know, obviously, things are difficult, but we're not used to AMETEK falling short, like it has over the last few quarters. Have you kind of too close to the Boeing potentially where it's becoming a little bit more difficult to guard against some of the shots in the market? Or are there other issues at play that you could maybe discuss?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, the key factor here is surely is not in terms of anything we've done in terms of cost reductions, et cetera. The key issue is that we have exposure on both sides of our company to markets that are in a pretty significant downturn. Oil and gas is a maj
componenttext: No, the key factor here is surely is not in terms of anything we've done in terms of cost reductions, et cetera. The key issue is that we have exposure on both sides of our company to markets that are in a pretty significant downturn. Oil and gas is a major part of our company and we had just seen, over the course of the last several quarters, that it has deteriorated further than we had expected. You may recall that we had called oil and gas in terms of the downturn last year, when we called it in January, we hit it right on. But this year, we did not hit it right on and the conditions are worse. If you look at oil and gas, we initially thought for 2016 with respect to 2015, we'd be down around $50 million. Our best look now is down around $90 million and that changed. There was an inflection point, actually, right around the time of our last earnings call when oil hit $26 a barrel. And when that happens, we just saw a large number of projects just moved to the right and -- that we were actually anticipating that we were going to get sooner. Most of those projects are still going to happen, but they're going to be moved and probably moved, many of them into next year. So we missed all that particular business and is simply because the changes have been so dramatic and it's very difficult to predict them. It has really nothing to do with how we are operating the company itself. It's just predicting the future is not an easy thing. And I would say, similarly, if you look at the other side of the company with the issue with medals pricing and the deflation that happened when we talked about this in the fourth quarter, in a way, a similar thing happened, that when metal prices went down so drastically, the buying levels from our customers just went very, very soft and have remain soft through the first quarter. And now the good news in that particular market is we are starting to feel improvements. We're -- actually, our order intake is improving so we actually believe that one will improve as the year goes on. But we're not predicting that the oil and gas business will improve. So this is, really, a market related issue with dramatic changes on each side of the company that's causing this problem. Now given that and the contribution margins of our businesses, we're actually quite pleased with the operating performance in terms of profitability. We've met our first quarter guidance on profitability. Margins, although down a bit, are still extremely good. One of the better ones in the industry. So we are managing a difficult situation as well as, I believe, anybody could manage it. But that's fundamentally what happened. I hope that helps.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And maybe just secondly, and obviously, there are a lot of numbers that are going into this, but I don't know if you could simplify it. When I just look at your bridge talking about flat sales for the year, obviously, 4%, 5%, 6-percentage points of acquis
componenttext: And maybe just secondly, and obviously, there are a lot of numbers that are going into this, but I don't know if you could simplify it. When I just look at your bridge talking about flat sales for the year, obviously, 4%, 5%, 6-percentage points of acquisition contribution organice down, I presume there hasn't been a change in the assumption on price and inflation, I guess, prices offset the inflation by a modest amount, still. And then you're talking about productivity savings of $130 million. I still have a hard time kind of bridging the guidance to the new range that has been provided. In fact, I'm actually coming above the range. So when I think about -- when I put together the qualitative components, I'm coming out to an EPS that should be higher than where you're guiding. I thought that probably for the last 4 or 5 quarters, and clearly that didn't materialize, but I was just curious if there are -- maybe you can kind of walk through some of the components that get you from the 2015 EPS to the 20 -- to your new guidance of -- the new guidance range that you provided today.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, actually you can do it in a relatively simple economic terms. The organic growth, if you look at the entire company, and you look at for the year, we think -- and our guidance assumes that we're going to be 2 points less on organic growth and that's
componenttext: Yes, actually you can do it in a relatively simple economic terms. The organic growth, if you look at the entire company, and you look at for the year, we think -- and our guidance assumes that we're going to be 2 points less on organic growth and that's a result of the 2 factors predominantly that I've talked about in answer to your first question. You take 2 points on a $4 billion company, that's $80 million. $80 million detrimental -- detrimental, excuse me, they are detrimental too, I guess, detrimental margins of this company, similarly to when they -- when volume goes up on the order of greater than 45%, roughly 50%. So just take the $80 million, multiply it, I'll take it to make the a number easy 50%, you got $40 million of pretax operating income and that's $0.12 or $0.13 a share. Yes, we haven't put it through more cost reductions, about $10 million of additional cost reductions over what we talked about last year or last quarter, excuse me, and you take that and what happens in many businesses when the economic environment gets tough is that basically people buy lower in the product portfolio so that the overall sort of mix of the company, for lack of a better word, goes down a bit. And that has, in essence, offset the $10 million of other cost improvements. In terms of price and inflation, what we told you at the beginning of the year was that we expected price to essentially offset inflation and that's still our expectation. So that is a very high level look. Obviously, there are puts and there are takes, but that's the overall thought process, and you take that and that is the reduction in the guidance essentially.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the investments spend of $60 million.
componenttext: And the investments spend of $60 million.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: $60 million on investment, absolutely. We have not changed the investment spend so we are continuing to make the investments so that when we get some -- a market list, the contribution margins are obviously going to be extremely high in the other directio
componenttext: $60 million on investment, absolutely. We have not changed the investment spend so we are continuing to make the investments so that when we get some -- a market list, the contribution margins are obviously going to be extremely high in the other direction and we're going to make a lot of money.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Allison Poliniak of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Allison Poliniak of Wells Fargo.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the energy side, Frank, let me just ask you. I know historically you'd have some level of visibility and  that's falling off again pretty dramatically with what's happened last financial crisis. I guess, what's your confidence now that we're sort of mo
componenttext: On the energy side, Frank, let me just ask you. I know historically you'd have some level of visibility and  that's falling off again pretty dramatically with what's happened last financial crisis. I guess, what's your confidence now that we're sort of modeling this well as we stand today? Obviously, oil's a little better right now, but I guess your confidence and just thoughts on the visibility as we move through this now?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure that's a great question and we have asked that same question of ourselves a number of times over the last few months. We're given this our best shot and from everything we know in talking with customers and also, quite frankly, listening to some
componenttext: Yes, sure that's a great question and we have asked that same question of ourselves a number of times over the last few months. We're given this our best shot and from everything we know in talking with customers and also, quite frankly, listening to some of our peer companies, I believe right now we got it called right. And we have not assumed any improvement in oil and gas as the year goes on. The levels are low. It's hard to believe they could get a little bit worse. But we also put a range on our guidance, so -- and the guidance is to be very clear. The guidance is balanced both ways, plus and minus. It's not a conservative estimate. It's what we really believe is going to happen. And if things do get a little weaker, we're going to be at the low end of the guidance. If things get to be a little bit stronger, we're going to be at the high-end of guidance. So we think we got it. But predicting the future is not an easy thing to do. But with our best people and our best thought process and it's fairly consistent with what other companies are saying. The only release that I saw that hinted at improvement in oil and gas at the latter part of this year was in GE's report. Just about everybody else, at least the ones I listened to and I don't listen to that many, maybe 4 or 5 were predicting pretty much what we are predicting.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just RD&E on that high-level of 5%. In this kind of environment, as the market to higher in terms of what you're investing in? I mean, any change to sort of the process now and sort of a softer version of the stronger market for you?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just RD&E on that high-level of 5%. In this kind of environment, as the market to higher in terms of what you're investing in? I mean, any change to sort of the process now and sort of a softer version of the stronger market for you?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's probably the last expense in the company that we do not like to touch. It's so critical to our future in terms of -- as you know, the level of technology on our products is quite high. And if you make dramatic cuts in that cost, you're going to hurt
componenttext: It's probably the last expense in the company that we do not like to touch. It's so critical to our future in terms of -- as you know, the level of technology on our products is quite high. And if you make dramatic cuts in that cost, you're going to hurt yourself. You won't see it for 2 or 3 years, so you can improve the short-term performance of the company, but not the -- you just don't want to sacrifice the long-term. So we have not made any substantial changes in that number. It's the same number that we talked about at the beginning of the year and it's also up over last year by that 5%. It is a lever that we would have if things did, by any chance, get any worse. But again, we don't anticipate that at this point in time.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Matt Summerville of Alembic.

componenttext: This is actually Nick Chin [ph] for Matt this morning. I was hoping that you can talk a little bit more about total and organic orders in terms of the backlog and what we're seeing for book and bill?

componenttext: Sure. Book-to-bill in the quarter was 1.02. Orders overall were up 3% organically. They were down 8%.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And then just finally, could you talk a little bit about the M&A funnel and just -- I know you sort of got into a little bit earlier, but just sort of your thoughts on the ability to deploy meaningful capital in regard to the balance
componenttext: That's very helpful. And then just finally, could you talk a little bit about the M&A funnel and just -- I know you sort of got into a little bit earlier, but just sort of your thoughts on the ability to deploy meaningful capital in regard to the balance sheet of 2016?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We feel real good that there's a high likelihood that we're going to be able to deploy a sizably larger amounts of capital as the years goes on. We have actually beefed-up our energy on the acquisition front. We've set up a couple other teams within
componenttext: Yes. We feel real good that there's a high likelihood that we're going to be able to deploy a sizably larger amounts of capital as the years goes on. We have actually beefed-up our energy on the acquisition front. We've set up a couple other teams within the company to look at opportunities. We're working with external advisers and we're -- we've got a lot that's in the pipeline. There are varying sizes from the smaller deals, like the 2 we talked about earlier in this meeting to larger deals. And I would say it's probably one of the top priorities of the company right now. We've got extremely strong cash flow and we believe that this is the best way for us to create value for our shareholders, while our markets are in a depressed condition.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Matt McConnell of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Matt McConnell of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Just to touch on the guidance reductions. $40 million is probably half or a little bit less than half than the guidance reduction that's the oil and gas piece.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: No. That's not right. No, you take $40 million -- this is pretax, $40 million at the pretax level, that goes to the bottom line at about $0.12 to $0.13.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. On the revenue side just going down to flat versus prior outlook for up and low single digit, that's about $100 million on revenue. And if oil and gas is $40 million, there is another bucket there that got weaker. Does that...
componenttext: Okay. On the revenue side just going down to flat versus prior outlook for up and low single digit, that's about $100 million on revenue. And if oil and gas is $40 million, there is another bucket there that got weaker. Does that...

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh yes. Now I got your question. The other part that I was talking about that on the EMG side, with the metal price deflation that I talked about, that's the other $40 million. So the total is not $100 million, it's about $80 million. The contribution mar
componenttext: Oh yes. Now I got your question. The other part that I was talking about that on the EMG side, with the metal price deflation that I talked about, that's the other $40 million. So the total is not $100 million, it's about $80 million. The contribution margins are a bit different between those two $40 million, it's actually higher on the oil and gas businesses and a bit lower than the 50% number that I was using. So you take the $80 million times the 0.5, you get basically $40 million of pretax and that's what I thought the original question was and that's how you get to the $0.12, $0.13 number.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Yes, it does. I'm thinking more along the lines of strictly end market weakness and top line weakness, what changed since February? And just getting at what might have gotten worse besides oil and gas? But...
componenttext: Okay, great. Yes, it does. I'm thinking more along the lines of strictly end market weakness and top line weakness, what changed since February? And just getting at what might have gotten worse besides oil and gas? But...

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is what I said in response to Brian is that, also the metals deflation in EMIP was deeper than we had anticipated and it's also slower coming back. Now we are seeing the trend, we're starting to come back, but it's not coming back at a rate that we thi
componenttext: It is what I said in response to Brian is that, also the metals deflation in EMIP was deeper than we had anticipated and it's also slower coming back. Now we are seeing the trend, we're starting to come back, but it's not coming back at a rate that we think could achieve the original guidance. And that's why we also reduced that part of the company by the $40 million. So it's a double hit. That's what's happening there. I mean, it's pretty simple, actually. We had a hit on the oil and gas and any idea and a hip on the AMF 1 and the even side and that's the core of what we're dealing with.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And just on the -- you mentioned it greater importance put on the operational excellence initiatives and that's up a bit, but the contribution would still be less than what you saw last year and I'm wondering if that's a realistic expectation
componenttext: Okay, great. And just on the -- you mentioned it greater importance put on the operational excellence initiatives and that's up a bit, but the contribution would still be less than what you saw last year and I'm wondering if that's a realistic expectation given the incremental effort that you're putting on those initiatives?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. If you remember last year, we said it when it happened, it was an exceptional year. We did several restructurings last year: one in the first quarter of 2015 and another one later in the year. So yes, that number last year was bigger, but I hope we s
componenttext: Yes. If you remember last year, we said it when it happened, it was an exceptional year. We did several restructurings last year: one in the first quarter of 2015 and another one later in the year. So yes, that number last year was bigger, but I hope we set the expectation that, that was not the run rate and what we're doing now at a $130 million level, we think it's pretty darn good and we feel great about it. And it comes back to one of the original or initial questions that you don't want to destroy these businesses, these are phenomenal businesses and you don't want to go in and take so much cost out that you then will not be able to recoup. So we think we've done the appropriate amount, we're pleased with it. You can see it in the overall performance of the company. And we're talking about earnings being down here, if you take the average of our estimates, about 32%. So it's not like we're going to be down 10% or 15% on earnings. So we're actually pretty happy with that, although I know it's not good from the change in guidance point.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Graham of BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Graham of BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to maybe slice this organic sales question a little bit differently. If we were to maybe pull out oil and gas and EMIP, it looks to me like your organic still would have been down, let's call it, 4% to certainly 5%, which is third deterioration i
componenttext: I wanted to maybe slice this organic sales question a little bit differently. If we were to maybe pull out oil and gas and EMIP, it looks to me like your organic still would have been down, let's call it, 4% to certainly 5%, which is third deterioration in the last 3 quarters, which of course includes those numbers as well. But the point, of course, is that the $80 million, if you straight line it, it's still kind of looks like organic was weaker than certainly I would've expected. So I guess my question is, one of your 4 operational model points, lays of the chair, if you will, is in fact new products and has there been thought given to maybe finding a way to bump up the cost reduction target a little bit more to let's say fund a little bit more organic growth? Because there's got to be some reason why the organic has been kind of weak for really 6 quarters now. So I was just wondering what you were thinking about in terms of your model, tweaking it to promote more organic.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, basically our strategies and clearly, RD&E and global and market expansion are definitely focused on the organic growth side of the business. If you look at the organic growth of AMETEK, Kevin has done this analysis over the last, almost any
componenttext: Well, I mean, basically our strategies and clearly, RD&E and global and market expansion are definitely focused on the organic growth side of the business. If you look at the organic growth of AMETEK, Kevin has done this analysis over the last, almost any periods you pick, say a year, 3 years, 5 years and it even has a 10 year chart, our organic growth lines up quite well with our peers. But obviously, when you've got the impact of these 2 market conditions that I'm talking about, it's not -- just not -- you can't overcome that. It's basically what happens. Your number, if you really look at it, isn't as significant as you think. It's not a 4% to 5%. It's a lower number than that. But it's running slightly negative, I would say, for the rest of the company and that's what's in our guidance. But the overwhelming impact is really from those 2 areas, and that'll change when those markets change. So in terms of tweaking the model, yes, we do that all the time and as I mentioned to Allyson's question, that's why we're keeping the RD&E expense up when the top line is weak. And sure, we're doing everything we can to help the organic growth picture of the company. And we're continuing to invest in higher growth regions of the world. And those are really the 2 key drivers to the organic side of the question.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. I was wondering if you could do your typical across the business divisions summary for us?
componenttext: Got it. I was wondering if you could do your typical across the business divisions summary for us?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Scott, I'd be glad to do that. So let me start with EIG. EIG Aerospace sales were down low single digits against the difficult comparison in last year's first quarter. We had very good growth in our commercial OEM and commercial aftermarket business
componenttext: Sure, Scott, I'd be glad to do that. So let me start with EIG. EIG Aerospace sales were down low single digits against the difficult comparison in last year's first quarter. We had very good growth in our commercial OEM and commercial aftermarket business in the quarter, but it was offset by difficult comparison in our business and regional business, which you may recall was very, very strong last year. For all of 2016, we expect EIG Aerospace sales to be up low to mid-single digits, again, driven by strength in our commercial OEM and commercial aftermarket businesses. Our process businesses, organic sales and process were down about 10% in the quarter, reflecting, obviously, what we've talked about in terms of greater than expected weakness in our oil and gas business. And as I mentioned, while some of the incremental weakness was in our upstream business, project delays and push outs also impacted our mid-and downstream business. And as a result, for all of 2016, we now expect sales for our process businesses to be down mid-single digits organically. And the last part of the EIG is Power & Industrial. There we had a solid first quarter. Overall sales are up 10% driven by the contributions from the acquisitions of ESP/SurgeX and Brookfield that I talked about in my opening comments. Organic sales were down low single digits and for all of 2016, we expect organic sales for Power & Industrial to be done a mid-single-digit number. So if you sum that all up for EIG, we're expecting overall sales to be roughly flat and that's obviously driven by the acquisitions of Brookfield and ESP/SurgeX with organic sales down to mid-single digit kind of region. Moving to the other half of the company, Scott, in EMG and the differentiated side, organic sales for our differentiated business were down high single digits versus the first quarter of 2015, driven largely by weakness across our engineered materials and interconnect and packaging business and the weakness, as I've already indicated, was really due to the impact of commodity price deflation. However, we do expect sequential improvement over the rest of 2016 and we're really facing that on current order trends, which have had strengthened and thus, we really do expect the stronger second half than first half. So if you sum all of that up for the differentiated piece for all of 2016, we expect our differentiated EMG businesses organic sales to be roughly flat versus the prior year. And the last and now much smaller part of our company, Floorcare & Specialty Motors, they were also down approximately 10% in the first quarter as a result of software global market conditions and for 2016, we expect sales for this business to be roughly flat organically versus prior year. You take those 2 parts of EMG. So overall, then, for EMG, we expect overall sales and organic growth to be roughly flat versus 2015. And then lastly, obviously, you saw EIG and EMG and that's where we get to the flat overall sales and organic sales down in the low to mid-single digits on a percentage basis.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Robert McCarthy of Stifel.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Robert McCarthy of Stifel.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So couple questions here. I mean one questions does come up from an investor is just thinking about, maybe drilling down on this question about size of deal. I think investors have been concerned about perhaps in the context of a lower structural organic
componenttext: So couple questions here. I mean one questions does come up from an investor is just thinking about, maybe drilling down on this question about size of deal. I think investors have been concerned about perhaps in the context of a lower structural organic growth and some of the challenges there, that doing a larger deal is kind of a priority just given the lower of large numbers. Can you just talk about your capacity to do a deal now of what size and then ultimately, how you think about your funnel? I know you did allude in previous comments how you're looking at a variety of deals and then clearly, there's some priority all things being equal to do a larger deal, could you talk about that particularly the context of I do think you brought up your revolver and your leverage a little bit this quarter. So could we get a sense of what is kind of the outward bound in your capacity right now?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. You got a questions in there. Let me start with what we consider a larger deal. First of all, we are not looking at mergers of equals here. If you look at most merger of equals, they don't create shareholder value. So when we look at the size o
componenttext: Yes, sure. You got a questions in there. Let me start with what we consider a larger deal. First of all, we are not looking at mergers of equals here. If you look at most merger of equals, they don't create shareholder value. So when we look at the size of deal that we are focused on, it's really between in volume between $50 million and a couple hundred million dollars and if a larger deal comes along up in the $400 million or $500 million region, we would consider doing that. In order to meet the model that we have discussed with you, where we basically want to achieve, on a yearly basis -- it's not going to be every year, but on average, 5% to 10% of our sales coming from acquisitions, that's the basic model we've talked about for years, you take the upper end of that and it's $400 million, right? We're $4 billion right now, so we're going to take the  upper end, 10%, you need to do $400 million in a volume and there's different ways you could say what's the purchase price based on that, but you take $400 million and multiply that by maybe 1.5 or 2, say 2, just to make the numbers easy, they got to deploy $800 million a year in capital, on average to make -- to get to the high end of that range. What's our capacity? Right now, our capacity is, with everything we've got, we are well in excess of $900 million in capacity. But more important than that, if you look at the free cash flow company, the operating cash flow is going to be this year on the order of $775 million, which means the free cash flow where our CapEx at around $70 million is around $700 million, so -- and when you buy companies, you got an EBITDA upstream. So basically, we could easily deploy $1 billion plus, probably $1.3 billion at the numbers recently without affecting significantly the leverage of the company. We will remain investment grade. That's an absolutely our thrust. We don't intend to flow equity. We don't need to based on the numbers that I just told you. So we're in a great position. Now if you look at it from the viewpoint of capacity from a management viewpoint, the way we have put the -- made changes in the company, really, over the last number of years, is to basically put enough resource in the company, which is already there now, it's already done so that we can handle 3 deals a year -- or 3 deals, simultaneously, excuse me. And if you take on average, how long it takes to do a deal, you could easily do 10  deals a year, probably even do a few more than that. The key point is, we don't have to do that larger deal. We can get that $400 million number by doing a bunch of small deals. But on the other hand, if we can find something and we looked at a few and we're actually very close on, one of the best larger we will do that. So we're not management constrained. We are not financially constrained from a cash flow viewpoint and it just comes down to finding really good companies. And we've got a lot of effort going in. The backlog is good. We're looking at deals. I can tell you that Dave and I are involved in deals on a daily basis. And I can't tell you exactly when the next one is going to close, but I can tell you that we're fairly optimistic that we're going to do well. And that's the best way that we can take the strong cash flow of the company and create value for you. So I don't know if I answered your question, I try to bundle them all together, but is that good?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of 2 other points, one on restructuring. Do you think we'll continue to see costs here going forward or just given -- how you think about this in the sense that what's ongoing and what should be just built into your earnings space just cost of do
componenttext: In terms of 2 other points, one on restructuring. Do you think we'll continue to see costs here going forward or just given -- how you think about this in the sense that what's ongoing and what should be just built into your earnings space just cost of doing business [indiscernible]...

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we think this number of, call it $100 million plus, we're at $130 million now, that's what we think we can do on a year end, year out basis. We've put the infrastructure in the company to do that and we believe that can continue for a substantial amo
componenttext: Yes, we think this number of, call it $100 million plus, we're at $130 million now, that's what we think we can do on a year end, year out basis. We've put the infrastructure in the company to do that and we believe that can continue for a substantial amount of time. And the majority of that is sort of built in to our revenue and our guidance as we give it to you guys and ladies. And the reason for that is the structure that we have put in place. As you know, we are an operationally focused company, so in terms of just our normal operational excellence strategies, we can get $50 million to $70 million a year and in terms of our materials strategy, we're in that same ballpark. And therefore, that's an ongoing cost. In terms of any, what I would call, major restructuring of the company, no, we're not envisioning that. And we have to modify the strategies as time goes on. And I'll give you an example, and Dave, maybe you can speak to this. On the material side, we've had a change of strategy a bit and we've done it incrementally over the last number of years and we've added a value analysis tool into our toolbox. And Dave, why don't you speak to that a little bit, you've really liked that activity and done a great job with it.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. It really comes down to getting that $50 million a year of cost savings that you talked about and for some of our mature businesses, where we've already globalized the supply chain, we really focused on targeting to build material from an engineerin
componenttext: Sure. It really comes down to getting that $50 million a year of cost savings that you talked about and for some of our mature businesses, where we've already globalized the supply chain, we really focused on targeting to build material from an engineering view point so we've taken our building materials, focused on the highest cost items and used both our engineering capability and supply chain capability to attack that. And very quickly, go through projects and we're introducing cost out designs in a matter 3 or 6 months. And we've done that across the company and we've institutionalized it as one of our Operational Excellence tools and now it's the largest driver of our material cost savings, so if you think about it, we bring a new company in, we go after the supply chain hard and we get big saving. Often it can 25% out of the company's material cost because of our global sourcing. While we've owned the company for 5 or 10 years, we had to find other avenues to take material cost out and that's where the value analysis, value engineering comes in and institutionalize across the whole business and as I mentioned, it's the largest driver of the material cost now so wer'e very happy about that.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Bhupender Bohra of Jefferies.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question, if you can give us some color on the BRIC countries especially in China?
componenttext: My question, if you can give us some color on the BRIC countries especially in China?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes, yes. Good news about it, it's the best way to say it. Overall, BRIC countries organically were down 8% and China was the driver, down about 9%. If you look at the other countries, Russia continues to be weak. Brazil, weak. Well actually a little
componenttext: Yes. Yes, yes. Good news about it, it's the best way to say it. Overall, BRIC countries organically were down 8% and China was the driver, down about 9%. If you look at the other countries, Russia continues to be weak. Brazil, weak. Well actually a little bit better than it was doing in terms of decremental oh organic growth versus last year. But, obviously, the driver here is China and I should mention India is good. That's the one that was good last quarter and it remains good. We had mid-single digit kind of organic growth in India. The good news is that we are feeling a stabilization in China, and if you look at the numbers we've provided over the last 3 quarters on China, they're not the best in the world, but the key thing is the orders in the first quarter were flat organically. So -- and in talking with our people there, they are feeling a bit of a stabilization, I would say, is probably the best word. So we're feeling a little bit better about China. But obviously, the BRIC countries, which, for a while for us, were growing at 25%, 30% overall, are now more of a challenge. But hopefully, what we saw in orders in China is an indication that things are going to get better there.

componenttext: Yes, basically, if you look at -- you're talking about the incremental $40 million that I talked about, it was evenly split between downstream at about $20 million and the combination of upstream and downstream at -- or upstream and upstream and downstream at $20 million. So $20 million at upstream, $20 million in the combination of mid-and downstream. I don't think I said that right a moment ago. Okay. And then between upstream or between midstream and downstream, it was more downstream oriented.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And the other $40 million on the metals business, now I thought when you saw the commodity prices jump in February, your customers would've actually commented by the metal, but I don't know.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Here's the -- great question, absolutely great question. The issue is what metals are key to AMETEK and in our case, the key metals on the EMIP side are molybdenum trioxide, cobalt, vanadium and to a lesser degree, nickel. And if you actually look at
componenttext: Yes. Here's the -- great question, absolutely great question. The issue is what metals are key to AMETEK and in our case, the key metals on the EMIP side are molybdenum trioxide, cobalt, vanadium and to a lesser degree, nickel. And if you actually look at those 3 metals, they're down and they have not come back. And that's why, when they do come back, our customers -- right now, they don't want to buy when they're very low, right? So we don't have an impact on our cost because we passed basically the price of the raw material on. So we're not sure of -- we don't have an issue from that viewpoint. The issue from us is when metal prices are very low, our customers are just going to hold up as long as they possibly can and -- before they start buying. And that's what's really happening right now. And it was -- and the fact that those metals have not rebounded yet is the issue. So you can't look at us in terms of the standard metals that you think of.

componenttext: So question on the full year guide versus the first half. Looks like we're implying a couple points of margin improvement in the second half versus the first. That's steep. So just wanted to get my brain around that.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We feel pretty comfortable as we move through the year in terms of the improvements and I'm going to talk of sort of about the overall improvements in EPS. And there's 3 drivers for this. The first is that in our process businesses, there's a seasona
componenttext: Yes. We feel pretty comfortable as we move through the year in terms of the improvements and I'm going to talk of sort of about the overall improvements in EPS. And there's 3 drivers for this. The first is that in our process businesses, there's a seasonality impact of several of our non-oil and gas related businesses, where they always have a stronger second half than first half. The second thing is that, in one of our oil and gas division's thermal process management, they have actually one market share with a good share of that improvement from the market share gain viewpoint already in backlog and they've done that, really, through several initiatives. The first was increase penetration in the Middle East and also a partnership that we have with [indiscernible]. So the first factor is, we expect the process businesses to have some improvement because of those factors.The second factor is, what we've already talked about in terms of EMIT, that we believe that situation and we are already seeing it in order intake, will have a gradual improvement through the year and therefore, we will see incremental improvements from that volume and we're very confident in that. And then the third thing is, really, the cost improvements. And if you look at how the cost improvements layer in, they become much more significant in the latter quarters in the year. So you take the organic growth of the first 2 reasons I outlined and obviously, when that goes to the bottom line, that improves your margins because of our very high contribution margins and then you put these incremental cost improvements through the business, that's why we feel those margins will in fact improve. Does that help?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's helpful. And then in terms of M&A, I think you did mention heightened focus on energy-related assets in particular. So if I heard that correctly, I'm wondering how you max that focus up against maybe gauging the risk of the commodities super c
componenttext: Yes, that's helpful. And then in terms of M&A, I think you did mention heightened focus on energy-related assets in particular. So if I heard that correctly, I'm wondering how you max that focus up against maybe gauging the risk of the commodities super cycle that could be a mirror image of the 10 year emerging markets boom?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Our focus is to fundamentally buy good businesses. We are not afraid of buying a business when it's in a down cycle. We believe oil and gas is going to be a good place to play on a longer-term and we are in a substantial down cycle. Now is oil is goi
componenttext: Yes. Our focus is to fundamentally buy good businesses. We are not afraid of buying a business when it's in a down cycle. We believe oil and gas is going to be a good place to play on a longer-term and we are in a substantial down cycle. Now is oil is going to get back to $125 a barrel? No, I don't think so. But I think it's reasonable to assume that is going to get back to a healthier level. So we're not afraid to buy assets. And you can get extremely, potentially extreme good pricing because you got businesses in distress and -- but it's not, I wouldn't say we're focused on oil and gas, I don't think I said that. I just said we -- we're not afraid to buy a business in the down cycle. Actually you have their home is a reverse problem. If you are very strong up cycle and you look at the sellers who were selling that business, they of course will take where they are at the top of the cycle and say they're going to grow organically from that point and they'll never put a cycle -- down cycle in their estimates. So you've got to be careful on that side of the equation. So we always put cycles in our acquisition models. We actually have an approach Monte Carlo analysis and change the magnitude of the cycles, change the timing of the cycles, et cetera, so that we make sure that we're paying the correct amount for the assets.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, that's a great point and if you recall what I said in one of the questions at that somebody asked in this meeting, right around the time we released guidance, I don't remember exactly when oil hit $26 a barrel, but we were starting to feel th
componenttext: Yes. I mean, that's a great point and if you recall what I said in one of the questions at that somebody asked in this meeting, right around the time we released guidance, I don't remember exactly when oil hit $26 a barrel, but we were starting to feel that. And so therefore, when I came out or we came out with guidance a quarter ago, I pushed you towards the low end and I did that because of the concern that did in fact materialize. Actually, I don't think I've ever done that before in my 16 you being the CEO. Normally, we come out with a very balanced view of the guidance, not the to push it one way or the other. And as I've already mentioned on this call, the guidance we're giving you now is balanced. Another words, we think there's as much upside potential as there is downside risk. So if things are weaker than what I'm saying, you could end up at the low end. If things are better, you're going to be at the high-end. So it's a balanced view. And it's not weighted in either of the direction. And so -- which is much more consistent with what we've done in the past.

componenttext: Covered a lot of ground and certainly a couple of questions. So you took up with your revolver in mid-March from $700 million to $850 million and is that a signal of may be size potential, maybe we get see in the M&A backlog? Or is it I'm I just reading too much into it?

componenttextpreview: It's a couple of factors and that was surely one of them that we have a lot of banks who are willing to give us a lot of funding so we took advantage of that. But also, you don't like the term of your revolver to get near the end. You have better negotiat
componenttext: It's a couple of factors and that was surely one of them that we have a lot of banks who are willing to give us a lot of funding so we took advantage of that. But also, you don't like the term of your revolver to get near the end. You have better negotiating power when you're not at the end. And so, that also entered into this. And there are some signals at some point in the future, interest rates are going to go up. So you've just been in a better negotiating position. So that -- really those 2 factors that drove it, Bob, I don't know if you have anything to add.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The bias is definitely towards M&A. I mean, we have said and said repeatedly that the best way we create value for our shareholders is by buying companies and making them better, and that is the primary use of capital. Having said that, we will do opportu
componenttext: The bias is definitely towards M&A. I mean, we have said and said repeatedly that the best way we create value for our shareholders is by buying companies and making them better, and that is the primary use of capital. Having said that, we will do opportunistic buybacks of stock. And I think Bob mentioned in his report that in the first quarter, we did some. It was 2.4 million shares. And we may very well continue that, but I don't want to imply that that's going to be a primary use of our cash. We can create better value for you by buying companies and improving.
