headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess -- obviously, tough end market conditions. But if I compare the last time we had big end market declines back in '09 to today, you held line of margins much better then. I'm just wondering maybe, Dave, if you could just maybe compare and contra
componenttext: So I guess -- obviously, tough end market conditions. But if I compare the last time we had big end market declines back in '09 to today, you held line of margins much better then. I'm just wondering maybe, Dave, if you could just maybe compare and contrast '09 to here? What led you to keep margins pretty flat to slightly up given that periods? And obviously, we've seen a bit more pressure today.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. That's a great question, Nigel. If you recall, 2009 was a much different than it is in the current environment. And all of the markets were down. And we talk action to deal with all the markets, then it returned very quickly. But in the current env
componenttext: Right. That's a great question, Nigel. If you recall, 2009 was a much different than it is in the current environment. And all of the markets were down. And we talk action to deal with all the markets, then it returned very quickly. But in the current environment, a couple of our markets are down, but some of our markets are hanging in there fine. The difference really is it's a much slower market and the market has [indiscernible] on for some time, and we have much higher margin company right now. If you remember that we were a mid-teens operating income margin company. Now we're much higher. And the 2 markets that are down about 20% of our company, oil and gas and metals, are down 30%. So that's a difficult headwind to offset, but we've done a good job to do it. We still have 22.4% operating margins, and we had a good operating quarter.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, no, I understand that. And then maybe a related question, just thinking about your exports from the U.S. You've got a relatively high U.S. export exposure. And I'm wondering the impact of the stronger U.S. dollar, particularly on your Process busine
componenttext: Okay, no, I understand that. And then maybe a related question, just thinking about your exports from the U.S. You've got a relatively high U.S. export exposure. And I'm wondering the impact of the stronger U.S. dollar, particularly on your Process business, what impact that's having on pricing within Process? And maybe on top of that, any hedge impact on margins would be helpful?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Yes, the question of price across our whole business, we were up about 1 point, and we had total inflation of a little less than that. So we're still a positive contribution. We are seeing additional headwinds, as you talked about, so we call that
componenttext: Right. Yes, the question of price across our whole business, we were up about 1 point, and we had total inflation of a little less than that. So we're still a positive contribution. We are seeing additional headwinds, as you talked about, so we call that flat for the year, meaning, price will offset inflation. So it's a different environment. In our Process businesses, they were very successful in expanding in the emerging markets, also very successful in the oil and gas market. So that is one point that we're seeing issues. Certainly, with a strong U.S. dollar when we're manufacturing in the U.S., we see competitive pressure because of the strong dollar. There is no doubt about that. We are dealing with that by relocating to low-cost locations. And in most situations, we don't have competitors in different market segments that give us an advantage. But in terms of the translation and transaction affects, now we're in a relatively stable environment, we're not seeing much effect. And you know we are naturally hedged in most of our markets. So I hope those answers your questions.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so pricing flat or price cost flat for the year?
componenttext: Okay, so pricing flat or price cost flat for the year?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Pricing is up 1 point across the business. And price less total inflation, that's all costs in the business, is still slightly positive for the quarter. But our outlook for the year is calling price less total inflation to be flat.
componenttext: Yes. Pricing is up 1 point across the business. And price less total inflation, that's all costs in the business, is still slightly positive for the quarter. But our outlook for the year is calling price less total inflation to be flat.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Rob McCarthy with Stifel.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Rob McCarthy with Stifel.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, a couple of questions. One, I think it was customary in the past that Frank would kind of go through the status of some of the subsegments, in terms of what we're seeing, in terms of growth and just a little bit of more color. If you could do that k
componenttext: Okay, a couple of questions. One, I think it was customary in the past that Frank would kind of go through the status of some of the subsegments, in terms of what we're seeing, in terms of growth and just a little bit of more color. If you could do that kind of state of the union through AMETEK, right now, that would be helpful.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Rob. I'll start with EIG Aerospace. EIG Aerospace sales were flat as compared to the last year, as we saw a continued strong growth across the commercial business that was offset by weakness in the business of regional jet market. For all of 2016, w
componenttext: Sure, Rob. I'll start with EIG Aerospace. EIG Aerospace sales were flat as compared to the last year, as we saw a continued strong growth across the commercial business that was offset by weakness in the business of regional jet market. For all of 2016, we expect a similar trend to continue as the second quarter, with the commercial market being strong and offsetting weaker business in regional jets. This business continues to draw -- deliver strong new program wins. These wins are across wide range of platforms, including commercial OEM, business in regional jets, military. And year-to-date, they have already won $230 million in [indiscernible] program wins. So we're really excited about the new business we're winning in that market, and you know that's important for the future of any aerospace business. Next up segment will be Process. Organic sales in Process were down mid-single digits in the quarter, driven largely by weakness across our oil and gas business. Our Ultra Precision Technology business performed very well in the quarter. That team has done an excellent job managing the business. And for all of 2016, we expect organic sales for our Process business to be down mid to high-single digits, driven by the weakness in oil and gas. Going to the EIG Power & Industrial subsegment, we have overall sales for our Power & Industrial businesses were up double digits, driven by the contributions of recent acquisitions, ESP/SurgeX and Brookfield. Organic sales were down mid-single digits in the quarter. And for all of 2016, we expect organic sales for Power & Industrial to be down mid-single digits versus 2015, which is unchanged from our prior forecast. So when you step back in 2016 for all of EIG, we expect overall sales to be down low single digits, with organic sales down mid-single digits. And if we switch to EMG, first, the differentiated parts of our EMG business. Organic sales were down mid-single digits, driven largely by continued weakness across our Engineered Materials Interconnects and Packaging business. We did see sequential stabilization in this business. However, the second-half improvements that we had anticipated are going to be delayed and delayed out of 2016. As a result, we expect second-half sales across our EMG businesses to be largely flat with the first half. And for all of our differentiated EMG business, we now expect organic sales to be down mid-single digits versus the prior year. And finally, our forecast in specialty motors business, although a small part of AMETEK, organic sales in our Floorcare & Specialty Motors business were down low teens in the second quarter, as a result of softer demand across our key markets. And for all of 2016, we expect this business to be down mid-single digits organically, as comparisons ease to the back half of the year. So if you look at all EMG, we expect overall sales to be down low single digits and organic sales to be down mid-single digits. And for AMETEK, we expect overall sales to be down low single digits and organic sales to be down mid-single digits on a percentage basis. Hope that helps.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Dave, thanks for that run through. I guess the next question, obviously, is kind of cadence of M&A, size of M&A. I mean, obviously, you have deployed a fair amount of capital here. You're in an environment where, I hate to typify it, but you have a r
componenttext: Yes, Dave, thanks for that run through. I guess the next question, obviously, is kind of cadence of M&A, size of M&A. I mean, obviously, you have deployed a fair amount of capital here. You're in an environment where, I hate to typify it, but you have a roading fundamentals with the margin, you had very high equity valuations which would imply high valuations for deals in both the public and private markets. So the bid ask is really kind of meddlesome at this point. I mean, do you think this causes a challenge to transacting deals or deals of size? And how do you think of a public deal? So I think that was an area of potential opportunity for you.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. You have a lot of questions there, I'll try to unpack them. I think the first point is, we have 4 deals done this year, and we deployed $360 million in free cash flow. And we're about halfway through the year, so we're pretty much on line for what
componenttext: Right. You have a lot of questions there, I'll try to unpack them. I think the first point is, we have 4 deals done this year, and we deployed $360 million in free cash flow. And we're about halfway through the year, so we're pretty much on line for what we're doing. So we agreed that the environment is tough, but we're still getting it done. The second point is we're bullish on our pipeline. We talked about expanding our pipeline past couple of quarters. And we're starting to benefit from the efforts of this pipeline identification efforts. And as you mentioned, you will recall, our sweet spot is that 4 [ph] -- $50 million to $200 million deal, but we've expanded our horizons now. We're looking for deals up to $500 million in revenue, and we're looking at both private and public companies. And we're really optimistic because our pipeline is starting to reflect the efforts of the last couple of quarters, as those businesses are working their way through the pipeline. So in terms of acquisitions, it is a tougher environment. We're getting deals done. We have a solid pipeline. We end up parsing those deals and selecting the deals to do that we can have the most value to, and we're still very selective. And it is a key driver of our future value enhancement. So I'm really optimistic. We have plenty of firepower, $1 billion of capacity within our existing credit lines and cash on hand. More importantly, our operating cash flow is $750 million. Free cash flow about $670 million, and I think this can be a significant driver for the balance of 2016 and 2017 performance.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Last question, if you'll indulge me. In terms of the guidance for the full year, you have visibility in kind of your end markets at the back half and some of the inventory challenges you've had in the stabilization. But is [indiscernible] suffice it to sa
componenttext: Last question, if you'll indulge me. In terms of the guidance for the full year, you have visibility in kind of your end markets at the back half and some of the inventory challenges you've had in the stabilization. But is [indiscernible] suffice it to say, you feel good about this guidance? Is it conservative? Is it unlikely we'll get another cut in the back half?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. There is not going to be another cut in the back half. We feel the business has stabilized. Key markets' headwinds have stabilized. And our second half looks very much like our first half.
componenttext: No. There is not going to be another cut in the back half. We feel the business has stabilized. Key markets' headwinds have stabilized. And our second half looks very much like our first half.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Graham with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Graham with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to chairing your first call, Dave. Unfortunately, it comes under not terrific auspices, but I certainluy did like the answer to -- or how you finished Rob's question just now. I guess maybe more surgically, I was wondering if you could tell us wha
componenttext: Welcome to chairing your first call, Dave. Unfortunately, it comes under not terrific auspices, but I certainluy did like the answer to -- or how you finished Rob's question just now. I guess maybe more surgically, I was wondering if you could tell us what were the pressure points on the second half effective guidance reduction here? What changed? You seemed to have pretty good line of sight. You gave us some really good numbers in the first quarter as to why the guidance needs to come down. Could you maybe do something similar to that for the second half to perhaps make us feel as good as you feel about the full year guidance at this point?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. There's kind of 2 parts in there. One, really, what's driving the take down, and why do we feel good about the stabilization? So I'll take the first point. Really, if you look at, it can explained really easily, economically. Our organic growth is dr
componenttext: Yes. There's kind of 2 parts in there. One, really, what's driving the take down, and why do we feel good about the stabilization? So I'll take the first point. Really, if you look at, it can explained really easily, economically. Our organic growth is dropping 2.5 points versus the prior forecast or approximately $100 million. And it's really driven by oil and gas and metals. That results in a 50% decremental. The oil and gas is one of our most profitable businesses. So you take that $50 million and you look at the numbers of shares we have, it turns out to $0.16, which fits right in the midpoint of the guidance range. So that's what happened economically. When we look out for the balance of the year, really our EMG business, we thought that was going to pick up and now it's not. And we can talk about that a little more in a bit, but fundamentally, we got comfortable with it because it's flat. We saw the same demand patterns in Q1 as we saw Q2, and we're forecasting that for the rest of the year. In terms of our oil and gas business, it drops lower than we initially anticipated. And we had modest improvements in that business. And now we're forecasting it flat. And when we look at that business, we really think it's bottomed, based on what our customers are telling us, based on some of the commentary you heard from Halliburton, Baker Hughes, Schlumberger, where rig counts bottomed in Q2. So that business is down, but we think it's bottomed. To your point how do we get comfortable with the stability in the year, I talked a little bit about the first half being the second half being similar. And really, embedded within our guidance is really our Q4. It's really a carbon copy of what we just did in Q2. So we're not really forecasting a major uptick in the second half. In fact, Q3 is down a bit seasonally because of some typical slowness that we've seen in Europe in the summer, and we have normal seasonality in Q4, but really, Q4 is very similar to Q2. And to your broader point about the forecast and how we're accurate, how we feel more confident, I mean, many of you have followed AMETEK for quite a while. And in the past, our forecasting process has yielded very consistent results, and it happened in the last few quarters. And it's a difficult environment where we have visibility away from our customers and demand is weak in many of our markets. Customers are delaying capital projects. Customers are managing [ph] inventory aggressively. The emerging markets are challenged. But all that said, we have to do a better job forecasting on environment. And I asked Bill and the group presidents to take a look at our forecasting products, Process, with the focus on making it more robust given the environment. So we took a different approach to forecasting. We got an entire executive office involved. We took a deep analytical review of each business to understand their forecasts and to better assess potential risk. We had conversations with the financial communities, so we understood what was happening. And although it was a more time-consuming process, we felt it's the right thing to do at this point. It allowed our executive office, which has a broader field of view than those of our P&L leader running our niche businesses, who by definition are only going to see a more narrower view of the global economy. We took that broader view. We applied a consensus view of risk. It's reflected on our guidance. And the final point, this is a rigorous process, and I feel confident in the results.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, that was very helpful. I very much appreciate that. But obviously the thing is that we -- with the exception of the new rigor and the new sort of construct you have around the guidance, we did hear that in the first quarter, oil prices are now lower
componenttext: Dave, that was very helpful. I very much appreciate that. But obviously the thing is that we -- with the exception of the new rigor and the new sort of construct you have around the guidance, we did hear that in the first quarter, oil prices are now lower again. I know it's a small business, but truck is falling apart. And then you have Brexit potentially affecting Europe. So if your reduction in guidance is only around oil and gas and metals, is there essentially a lift in the cost savings number to make sure you get there? That's kind of where I may be coming up short.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Yes. Our cost reductions are $130 million for the year, so it's the same number that we communicated last quarter. And really, on a lower volume, we are purchasing less material, but we're confirming the $130 million number, so the cost reduction i
componenttext: Right. Yes. Our cost reductions are $130 million for the year, so it's the same number that we communicated last quarter. And really, on a lower volume, we are purchasing less material, but we're confirming the $130 million number, so the cost reduction is embedded in it. You mentioned Brexit, there is a situation where we are balanced in revenues and expenses. We have 5% of our sales in the U.K. We're balanced in revenues and expenses. So we have a natural hedge. So we're not going to have any transaction or translation surprise. So we expect a short-term impact to be minimal. We've been checking with our U.K. businesses on a weekly basis. We haven't seen any downturn in orders yet, mainly because we're in a market that's not maybe tied to the consumer there. And you're right, longer-term impact, it will be driven with the economic growth on the European and the global growth, and this uncertainty is going to go on for some time, but we are feeling pretty good about our exposure. And there are weak global macro conditions. I mean, we highlighted oil and gas and metals, but certainly, the global economy is not good, and yet, the spillover effect from oil and gas into the other markets. So all the markets are tough. Again, with the first half and the second half, they're essentially carbon copies of each other, and we are very comfortable with it.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Allison Poliniak with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Allison Poliniak with Wells Fargo.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, I just wanted to go back, you said sort of that metals commentary. I guess, high level, I agree we would have thought that we would have seen improvement there. Can you kind of walk us through what happened? What changed in that business that's driv
componenttext: Dave, I just wanted to go back, you said sort of that metals commentary. I guess, high level, I agree we would have thought that we would have seen improvement there. Can you kind of walk us through what happened? What changed in that business that's driving sort of a lower expectation for the back half now?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, sure. First, let me take a moment. In this business, we take metals, metals such as titanium, vanadium, cobalt, nickel, molybdenum, and process them with very unique processing capabilities into specialty alloys, powders, components, and we're very
componenttext: Right, sure. First, let me take a moment. In this business, we take metals, metals such as titanium, vanadium, cobalt, nickel, molybdenum, and process them with very unique processing capabilities into specialty alloys, powders, components, and we're very -- we have strong niche positions, and we feel very good about this business. What's happening is 2 things, visibility and inventory. In this business, we tend to be 4 or 5 levels removed from the ultimate end customer or application. So as a result, the visibility is limited. And we can get misaligned with a broader end market demand, given the inventory buildup in the channel. And we're seeing this play out right now. To give you a tangible example, we produced specialized master alloys, which is a critical component in the making of titanium parts of a aircraft. We're one of the few producers who can make the specialized alloy, but we're far down removed on the food chain. So we sell to a titanium melter, who sells to an ingot maker, who sells to a part manufacturer, who sells to subassembly manufacturer, who eventually gets on the airframe. So we're quite a way removed in this business different than most of our businesses. And we really -- we identify some secondary inventory locations who has some inventory. So although the long-term demand for titanium master alloy, in this case, in aircraft is very strong with new aircraft using more titanium, the short-term demand for alloy is being impacted by this excess inventory in the supply chain.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is there any sense of when that excess inventory would be cleared?
componenttext: Is there any sense of when that excess inventory would be cleared?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's not going to clear in 2016, but we are still bullish that it's still going to clear and it will be in 2017.
componenttext: Yes. It's not going to clear in 2016, but we are still bullish that it's still going to clear and it will be in 2017.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then on the new acquisition, you had talked about expanding into and enter the new market. Can you expand on that, like where would that sort of end new market be?
componenttext: That's helpful. And then on the new acquisition, you had talked about expanding into and enter the new market. Can you expand on that, like where would that sort of end new market be?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, right. That's a great question. You're talking about Nu Instruments. They are very analytical high-end magnetic sector mass spectrometers. And the markets that we're in currently are similar to the markets that our CAMECA business is in. The research
componenttext: Yes, right. That's a great question. You're talking about Nu Instruments. They are very analytical high-end magnetic sector mass spectrometers. And the markets that we're in currently are similar to the markets that our CAMECA business is in. The research market in environmental, I mean in the environmental sciences, material characterization, nuclear -- but the one new market that we're interested in is they have a new product that's in the food and beverage testing market. And the interesting thing about it -- in the news, there's a lot of questions about food contamination. And the interesting thing about the Nu equipment is it's just so sensitive and has a unique processing capability. It can actually tell if there's a contamination, and it's sensitive enough to tell where in the world the food is from. So we're very optimistic for the food testing market. In that business, if you take a step back, the business had basically one salesperson, and they have great technology. And we're going to plug it into our CAMECA business with a tremendous sales and service network, and really optimistic about the potential for Nu.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Christopher Glynn with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Christopher Glynn with Oppenheimer.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: You referenced a bit of a 3Q step down clearly on the EPS. Is that all volume-related? And what exactly drives the step back in 3Q versus the kind of run rates for the year?
componenttext: You referenced a bit of a 3Q step down clearly on the EPS. Is that all volume-related? And what exactly drives the step back in 3Q versus the kind of run rates for the year?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. It just changed from Q2 to Q3 as it can be explained by lower sales volume. So our EPS is lower because of volume. And typically, we have -- Europe has some slower months, and we have seasonality in Q3 that drops back a bit. And in Q4, there's real
componenttext: Right. It just changed from Q2 to Q3 as it can be explained by lower sales volume. So our EPS is lower because of volume. And typically, we have -- Europe has some slower months, and we have seasonality in Q3 that drops back a bit. And in Q4, there's really our normal seasonality. And as I said before, Q4 is really a carbon copy of the quarter we just completed. So we feel pretty good about it.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, makes sense. And then on the deals that you mentioned, the $150 million total sales acquired to-date, disclosed new if I look at the first quarter deals. I stick it all in place, HS Foils is similar in size? Do I have that right?
componenttext: Okay, makes sense. And then on the deals that you mentioned, the $150 million total sales acquired to-date, disclosed new if I look at the first quarter deals. I stick it all in place, HS Foils is similar in size? Do I have that right?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the number is wrong. It was $115 million.
componenttext: Yes. I think the number is wrong. It was $115 million.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: $115 million. Got it.
componenttext: $115 million. Got it.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So what you really have with Nu, we paid a price that was a little more than 2x sales, close to 2x sales, and it's 9x the first year EBITDA. And HS Foils is smaller. It's significantly smaller. It's a technology acquisition, that's really going to help us
componenttext: So what you really have with Nu, we paid a price that was a little more than 2x sales, close to 2x sales, and it's 9x the first year EBITDA. And HS Foils is smaller. It's significantly smaller. It's a technology acquisition, that's really going to help us drive organic growth, and we're optimistic about it. But it's in the low millions of dollars, in terms of the technology.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Matt McConnell with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Matt McConnell with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the specialty metals business. So -- and I certainly understand that these end markets are fundamentally pretty healthy. So is this a permanent change in how the supply chain is managing inventory? Or are there any competitive shifts g
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the specialty metals business. So -- and I certainly understand that these end markets are fundamentally pretty healthy. So is this a permanent change in how the supply chain is managing inventory? Or are there any competitive shifts going on here that are notable? And just any permanent change in the level of activity in the specialty metals business?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it's not a permanent change, Matt. I mean, it's an issue where the metals market that I talked before about the complex supply chain is kind of in between us and really good end markets. And that market is in -- it's in distress right now. So the cust
componenttext: No, it's not a permanent change, Matt. I mean, it's an issue where the metals market that I talked before about the complex supply chain is kind of in between us and really good end markets. And that market is in -- it's in distress right now. So the customers are managing their inventories for cash. They are being very aggressive in terms of working capital, but long term, we're very bullish. I mean, if you look at the titanium used in aircraft, if you look at -- that's all growing with the A350 and the 787. If you look at the other end market applications in medical and specialized, industrial, we're very bullish. I mean, certainly, we have an FX that's creating headwinds with that business and along with some of our other businesses. But there really is no competitive dynamic that's major and the market is going to return and have good businesses and good positions, and we just have to wait it out. And we -- I talk a lot about the visibility in the inventory, but that's the key factor. It is not an issue or it's not going to come back.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so following up on some of the stabilization comments you made, you gave great insight around your level of conviction to that comment for oil and gas, some customer comments and actions. How about outside oil and gas? Any other -- do you have orders
componenttext: And so following up on some of the stabilization comments you made, you gave great insight around your level of conviction to that comment for oil and gas, some customer comments and actions. How about outside oil and gas? Any other -- do you have orders or backlog? Or any other comments to give you confidence about stabilization in the other parts of your business?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Our backlog is $1.1 billion. I mean, if we look at the run rates, then we spend a lot of detail on it, it gives us confidence for the back half of the year. So again, we mentioned that the metals business is already performing from -- in that flat se
componenttext: Yes. Our backlog is $1.1 billion. I mean, if we look at the run rates, then we spend a lot of detail on it, it gives us confidence for the back half of the year. So again, we mentioned that the metals business is already performing from -- in that flat sequential from Q1 to Q3. There's not much changed in the other parts of our business, and there's not much changed in the market. You really have a slow global macro environment, and the 2 things we've been trying to get our hands around are really oil and gas and metals, but the balance of the business is performing as we expected.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Richard Eastman with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Richard Eastman with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave -- or maybe this is a question for Bill. But could you just explain the decremental EBIT in EIG, roughly flat core sales? We delivered something like $9 million less in profit. Is that all mixed shift with oil and gas being weak?
componenttext: Dave -- or maybe this is a question for Bill. But could you just explain the decremental EBIT in EIG, roughly flat core sales? We delivered something like $9 million less in profit. Is that all mixed shift with oil and gas being weak?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think in EIG, we had a negative 6% core. So what you're seeing is roughly, I think it's a 50% kind of decremental margin in that business. You've got some of the higher-margin businesses going down. And that's really what's driving the decline quarter-o
componenttext: I think in EIG, we had a negative 6% core. So what you're seeing is roughly, I think it's a 50% kind of decremental margin in that business. You've got some of the higher-margin businesses going down. And that's really what's driving the decline quarter-over-quarter in terms of the profitability in the business.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Another point I'd add to that, Richard, is really if you think about what happened last year, our mid and downstream oil and gas business were still running very strong. So you have that business that's very profitable, and now it's started down. So that'
componenttext: Another point I'd add to that, Richard, is really if you think about what happened last year, our mid and downstream oil and gas business were still running very strong. So you have that business that's very profitable, and now it's started down. So that's one of the profit impacts in Q2 year-over-year.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I noticed from your comments, Dave, when you kind of laid out some of the subsegment expectations for sales, the cost-driven motors business now is going to be down mid-single digits versus flat. But probably more to the point, the EIG Aero
componenttext: Okay. And then I noticed from your comments, Dave, when you kind of laid out some of the subsegment expectations for sales, the cost-driven motors business now is going to be down mid-single digits versus flat. But probably more to the point, the EIG Aerospace commentary suggests the second half is flat and maybe the full year turns out to be flat -- plus low single to the plus mid-single. So has there been a downshift on the Aerospace side in that regional biz jet market?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The regional biz jet market, if you recall, in 2015, we talked about some wins, some new product wins and some retrofit opportunities. And this year, really in that regional business jets, we're down about 18%. And you have some of the wins we talked
componenttext: Yes. The regional biz jet market, if you recall, in 2015, we talked about some wins, some new product wins and some retrofit opportunities. And this year, really in that regional business jets, we're down about 18%. And you have some of the wins we talked about -- I'll throw a couple of examples out with Honda jet. While we're designed into the Honda jet, we're making significant shipping commitments, but the Honda jet has been delayed. So there is a -- that market is down. We were overperforming in 2015 when the market was flat, and we're really at the market levels, but dropping back, and I'd point to some programs that are not repeating or delayed. The commercial market is strong, and there's really no change in that. There, we have -- if you look historically, we've been mainly a Boeing airframe company, and over the past 10 years, we diversified our market to be even between Boeing and Airbus, so we're kind of don't care who wins. We win them with both. And we got more content on newer aircraft. So even though the airframes are relatively flat, we're still growing in commercial, and we feel good about that right now.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just 1 maybe a strategic question for you, Dave. As you kind of step in the role, and I know there is kind of bullets flying all over the place here in terms of end market conditions, but, historically, AMETEK has targeted this framework where ou
componenttext: And then just 1 maybe a strategic question for you, Dave. As you kind of step in the role, and I know there is kind of bullets flying all over the place here in terms of end market conditions, but, historically, AMETEK has targeted this framework where our core businesses and our core business prospect are kind of plus 5%, and then we're going to add 10% through M&A. But again, given where we are with the acquisitions over the last 5 years on the metals side, our oil and gas exposure was bigger than we had thought perhaps. But how do you feel about the next 3 -- the 5 years targeting a core growth rate for your current mix of businesses? I mean, should we think about that downshifting to more of a GDP number? And then we'll have fits and starts that may be are plus or minus the GDP? Is that a more realistic view given the set of businesses and the mix of business that you have kind of inherited and are now moving forward?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I see your point. I mean it's difficult to predict what's going to happen in the first few years. And I get a lot of assessment of AMETEK's performance, obviously, before I got into the role and in the role. And I'm a bit biased and look at our earni
componenttext: Yes, I see your point. I mean it's difficult to predict what's going to happen in the first few years. And I get a lot of assessment of AMETEK's performance, obviously, before I got into the role and in the role. And I'm a bit biased and look at our earnings growth through the cycle in the last 10 years, we grew 116% compounded annually. And I give myself a good grade on that, an A. Margins, same kind of thing. Highest margins in the industrial space. The cash flow generation has been outstanding. Our return on capital, well in excess of our cost of capital. And our capital deployment has been excellent. We're using our free cash flow to acquire good businesses and make them better. But in my role -- dealing with your question, organic growth is important. And certainly, over the next few years when the environment can be slower, we can deal with flatter markets, I'm taking the current aftermarket headwinds aside with oil and gas and metals, but separate from that, when we return to more flattish, stabilized markets, [indiscernible] that our strategy to the potential new reality in the marketplace. And really, when I look at it, to ensure that we're going to be able to double our earnings over the next 5 years by low to mid-single-digit organic growth and adding on acquisitions of 5% to 10% a year, we need to do a better job with organic growth. And our organic growth, we've been average. We've been average compared against some good companies, but we can definitely improve. So we can do this under the construct of our existing growth strategies and expand our Operational Excellence toolkit, and put more tools in that tool kit to focus on our sales and marketing processes, really making the front end of our business as good as our operations. And that's going to be an area of focus for me and my team, and it's going to take some time. It's not going to be something that moves the needle in the short term, but I'm confident it can get better. So we're focused on making organic growth better to your exact question. I think in a slow environment, we're going to have to boost it a little bit to get that low to mid-single-digit organic growth that allow us to double the earnings of the company.

componenttext: This is Akshay Bhatia on for Andrew. I just wanted to dig in to your energy exposure a little bit. Could you remind us what your exposure is between upstream, midstream and downstream after a couple of years of downturn? And maybe could you talk about some of the trends you saw over the course of the quarter, maybe how April compared to June, across these different business line?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. It was difficult to hear you, but I think I have your question. Yes, the oil and gas business, as we talked before, was lower than forecasted in Q2, but stabilized. So we saw orders in that second quarter that really matched our Q3 volume levels, s
componenttext: Right. It was difficult to hear you, but I think I have your question. Yes, the oil and gas business, as we talked before, was lower than forecasted in Q2, but stabilized. So we saw orders in that second quarter that really matched our Q3 volume levels, so we feel good about that. Coming into the year, it was about $360 million business from AMETEK. About 1/3 of that is upstream, 1/3 of that is midstream and 1/3 of that is downstream. The business is 1/3 in the U.S. and 2/3 International. So we have $120 million takedown this year. So the $360 million is going to be down $120 million, that's about 1/3, and it's about $60 million down in upstream and $60 million down in the combination of mid- and downstream. So if you look at our upstream exposure, that's down about 60% and our mid- and downstream exposure is about 20%.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I know you talked about pricing overall being up 1%, but maybe could you discuss pricing that you're seeing specifically in the energy market?
componenttext: And I know you talked about pricing overall being up 1%, but maybe could you discuss pricing that you're seeing specifically in the energy market?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The pricing in the energy market is below the average of the whole company. It's a very difficult environment. They have had to reduce costs to stay in business. We still can maintain pricing because we have very premier positions with niche-differen
componenttext: Yes. The pricing in the energy market is below the average of the whole company. It's a very difficult environment. They have had to reduce costs to stay in business. We still can maintain pricing because we have very premier positions with niche-differentiated technologies, but it's certainly not at the AMETEK level on average, and it's up or down a bit in the energy market, more in the upstream than the mid- and downstream.

If you can give us some color how the emerging markets did actually in the quarter? Because oil and gas is like 2/3 is international. I just wanted to get a sense of how it did in like in Europe, Asia Pacific and outside the U.S?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, Bhupender. I'll go around the world. In the U.S., we were down high single digits versus last year. There are broader industrial weakness, but the key factors driving the negative growth for oil and gas and metals. In Europe, it's been -- it wa
componenttext: Yes, sure, Bhupender. I'll go around the world. In the U.S., we were down high single digits versus last year. There are broader industrial weakness, but the key factors driving the negative growth for oil and gas and metals. In Europe, it's been -- it was down low single digits, so we've been at that level for several quarters. Oil and gas impacted the region, but we don't have much metals exposure in Europe. And in Asia, we were down mid-single digits. And China was down mid-single digits, so there is a little bit of an improvement in China. There's a trend for Asia where we were down double digits for 3 quarters in a row, and now we're down mid-single digits, and China was a negative 4%. So orders for the region, the entire Asia region were a little bit better than prior year, so it seems to be that Asia is stabilizing, China is stabilizing. And the one emerging market that I point out is doing better than the others is India, at about the mid-single digit growth in India. It's a much smaller exposure, but our investment there are paying off.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And how should we think about how these markets would act? Or what kind of assumptions do you have for the second half? Like, which of these markets would be kind of remaining stable or along the lines you just mentioned or they would deteriorate further?
componenttext: And how should we think about how these markets would act? Or what kind of assumptions do you have for the second half? Like, which of these markets would be kind of remaining stable or along the lines you just mentioned or they would deteriorate further?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. If I look at the trends in the U.S., even though we're down high single digits, it's slightly better from last quarter. Europe, that same trend is continuing. And Asia, we're improving a bit. But really, we don't have anything factored in. It's reall
componenttext: Yes. If I look at the trends in the U.S., even though we're down high single digits, it's slightly better from last quarter. Europe, that same trend is continuing. And Asia, we're improving a bit. But really, we don't have anything factored in. It's really down mid-single digits. So geographic-wise, it's squared with our concept of stabilization. I mean, fundamentally, our business has stabilized, and we are working on earnings growth for 2017 now. We are focused on our business. We are getting ready to go into our budgeting process. And that budgeting process that we go through in Q3 and spreads into Q4, there's really no area immune from efficiency improvement. We're going to look at things like global sourcing, low-cost region production, value analysis, value engineering, plant consolidations, India engineering, all the tools that we have, and we're going to get a healthy cost-reduction target. And we're going to pair that with acquisitions, and that's how we're going to grow earnings next year. So geography is not a big factor in thinking through what we have to do for the balance of the year or what we have to do next year.

componenttext: Okay. Now how should we think about like the back half of this year? Are we -- any assumptions here where the focus will be more on the cost side as the macro is kind of [indiscernible]?

componenttext: Right, right. For the year, we're saying operating income margins will be down 130 to 170 basis points. And longer term, I mean given all the -- given our high margin contribution margin businesses and given our operational excellence capabilities, as far as the eye can see, when we get out of these market conditions and we return to internal growth, we have the same 30 bps margin expansion for the long term.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Good morning. Thank you, everyone, for joining us for our Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. With me this morning are Dave Zapico, Chief Executive Officer; and Bill Burke, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. AMETEK's second
componenttext:
Great. Good morning. Thank you, everyone, for joining us for our Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. With me this morning are Dave Zapico, Chief Executive Officer; and Bill Burke, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. AMETEK's second quarter results were released earlier this morning. These results are available electronically on market systems and on our website at the Investors section of AMETEK.com.
This call is also webcasted. It can be accessed on our website and at streetevents.com. The call will be archived on both of these sites.
Before we get started, I will remind you that any statements made by AMETEK during the call that are not historical in nature are to be considered forward-looking statements. As such, these statements are subject to change based on various risk factors and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ significantly from expectations. A detailed discussion of the risks and uncertainties that may affect our future results is contained in the AMETEK's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. AMETEK disclaims any intention or obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements.
I'll also refer you to the Investors section of AMETEK.com for a reconciliation of any non-GAAP financial measures used during this call. 
We will begin with some prepared remarks by Dave and Bill, and then we will open it up for questions. I'll now turn the meeting over to Dave.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kevin. Good morning.AMETEK delivered second quarter results that were in line with our expectation, reflecting the strong efforts of our businesses in managing in a challenging global environment. Also, subsequent to the end of the second qua
componenttext:
Thank you, Kevin. Good morning.
AMETEK delivered second quarter results that were in line with our expectation, reflecting the strong efforts of our businesses in managing in a challenging global environment. Also, subsequent to the end of the second quarter, we acquired 2 businesses, Nu Instruments, a leading provider of magnetic sector mass spectrometers, and HS Foils, a provider of radiation detector components. Both are excellent strategic fits with existing AMETEK businesses. I will talk further about these acquisitions in a moment, but let me first provide the financial highlights for the quarter.
Sales were in line with expectations in the second quarter at $977.7 million, down 3%. Organic sales were down 7%, while acquisitions added 4%. The impact from currency in the quarter was negligible. Operating income was $219 million and operating income margin was 22.4%. Diluted earnings per share were $0.59, down 8% over last year's second quarter and at the high end of our guidance range. Operating cash flow was very solid in the second quarter at $189 million, up 16% from last year's second quarter. Free cash flow converged into net income was a strong 126%.
Now turning to the individual operating groups.
First, the Electronic Instruments Group. Sales of $596 million were in line with last year's second quarter. Organic sales were down 6%. Acquisitions contributed 6%. And foreign currency was flat. The contributions from recent acquisitions of Brookfield and ESP/SurgeX were offset in large part by the weakness across our oil and gas business. As noted, we continued to face challenging conditions across our oil and gas business. Despite the modest rebound in the price of oil from its February lows, customers remain cautious. They continue to defer maintenance work, and capital projects are being delayed. However, it appears as if conditions are stabilizing at lower levels than we previously anticipated.
EIG's operating income in the second quarter was $152.1 million, and operating margins were a strong 25.5%.
The Electromechanical Group reported overall sales of $381.7 million, down 6% versus the second quarter of last year. Organic sales were down 8%. Acquisitions contributed 2%. And foreign currency was flat. EMG sales remain pressured by weakness across our Engineered Materials, Interconnects and Packaging businesses, driven largely by the continued headwinds from our specialty metals business. This business has stabilized. However, we do not anticipate improvements in the second half as we previously expected.
EMG's operating income was $80.3 million in the quarter, and operating margins were a solid 21%.
Now let me provide background on the 2 acquisitions we announced this morning.
First, Nu Instruments. Nu Instruments manufactures magnetic sector mass spectrometers used for elemental and isotopic analysis. Nu's mass spectrometers utilize the magnetic field to separate the isotopes of elements in order to analyze the material characterization of a sample. Their products are used in advanced laboratory analysis within Earth and Environmental Sciences, material characterization and nuclear applications. Nu is an excellent strategic fit with our CAMECA advanced elemental analysis business.
Nu's strong R&D capabilities and highly complementary product offering will allow us to expand our presence in existing markets, while opening up opportunities to expand in new, attractive market segments. In addition, Nu will be able to leverage CAMECA's strong global sales and service channels to help accelerate growth.
Nu Instruments is headquartered in Wrexham in the U.K. with additional offices in Beijing and Tokyo. It has annual sales of approximately $25 million.
The second acquisition is HS Foils. HS Foils develops and produces the key components used in radiation detectors. Each component includes ultrathin radiation windows, Silicon Drift Detectors and x-ray fillers. HS Foils is an excellent technology acquisition for AMETEK. It provides us with unique patented intellectual property around silicon nitride window technology as well as extensive knowledge in silicon PIN and Silicon Drift Detector manufacturing.
HS Foils' technology will enable world-class instrument performance across many of our materials analysis businesses, including AMETEK, EDAX, SPECTRO and CAMECA. In addition, HS Foils operates out of a state-of-the-art semiconductor fab in Helsinki, Finland, which will help accelerate new product development initiatives.
With these 2 acquisitions, we have now deployed approximately $360 million capital and acquired over $115 million in revenue on 4 acquisitions so far in 2016. Our business unit and corporate teams remain active in identifying and pursuing acquisition opportunities, and we remain encouraged with the acquisition pipeline. The highest priority for capital deployment remains acquisitions.
Let me transition from highlighting our recent acquisitions to highlighting an acquisition we completed in 2013.
Creaform, which we acquired in October 2013, is a leading provider of 3D measurement technologies and services. They are the industry leader in standalone portable 3D scanners. Creaform's optically based devices are used across a number of high-growth applications within the Aerospace, automotive and general industrial markets. Key applications for their products include reverse engineering, dimensional inspection, precision manufacturing, automated quality control and 3D printing.
Creaform has been a tremendously successful acquisition for AMETEK, with impressive results across all key financial and operational metrics. They have leveraged AMETEK's growth strategies to help deliver outstanding results. Here are just a few of the highlights of their success. Organic sales have grown at double-digit rates since acquisition. Operating margins have more than doubled. Working capital as a percentage of sales has improved over 700 basis points to its current level over approximately 13% of sales. And sales from new products have increased from just over 40% to now nearly 65%.
This new product capability has been an important driver of Creaform's success. They have introduced a number of innovative new products, which help them penetrate new markets and capture additional share in their existing markets.
Most recently, Creaform's new lineup of quality control solutions were awarded the prestigious Red Dot Best of the Best award for their quality and breakthrough designs. For over 60 years, Red Dot has been one of the largest and most influential independent product competitions in the world. So this is a great honor.
Specifically, Creaform's products were recognized for their unmatched accuracy and reliability of the 3D measurements in harsh and unstable production environments. The new Creaform products recognized are the HandyPROBE Next, the MetraSCAN 3D and the C-Track.
Within Global & Market Expansion, the Creaform team has done an outstanding job actively expanding and growing the strong market presence and quality control in reverse engineering into new markets, such as nondestructive testing and healthcare. Creaform has also expanded their aftermarket calibration and repair capabilities globally to help further improve their value to their customers while also leveraging AMETEK's global footprint to expand the direct sales activities in the U.S., Brazil and Southeast Asia. I would like to congratulate the Creaform team for their tremendous efforts and outstanding success. They have created a truly dynamic business through the execution of our growth strategies.
Now let me take a moment to comment on current market conditions and their impact on our outlook for 2016. We fully understand and acknowledge the headwinds we face in this environment, given our mix of end market exposures. These headwinds, especially within the oil and gas and metals market, have been deeper and more sustained than we initially expected when we started the year.
Visibility has remain limited as customers are cautious and are aggressively managing their inventory levels in capital-spending plans.
As we look ahead to the balance of the year, we believe the business has stabilized. We do not anticipate a modest second-half improvement as we had expected, but rather believe demand in the second half to be largely consistent with the first half. As a result, we now forecast 2016 revenue to be down low single digits on a percentage basis from 2015 with organic sales down mid-single digits.
We expect earnings for 2016 to be in the range of $2.28 to $2.32 per diluted share, down 9% to 11% from 2015's adjusted diluted earnings per share. Third quarter 2016 sales are expected to be down mid-single digits versus the third quarter of 2015. And we estimate our earnings to be $0.54 to $0.55 per diluted share.
In summary, we remain focused on executing our 4 growth strategies despite economic uncertainty in many of our markets. We will continue to aggressively manage our business in the short term, while ensuring we continue to make appropriate investments in our businesses to properly position us for 2017 and beyond. While we have short-term market headwinds, I am very bullish on the opportunity for AMETEK to drive meaningful earnings growth and shareholder returns moving forward.
Our balance sheet remains strong. We generate significant cash flows that provides us with plenty of liquidity to operate the business and pursue our acquisition strategy. Our businesses are highly differentiated with strong market positions and excellent profitability. We have rightsized the cost structure, and we'll realize meaningful incremental margins as the current market headwinds subside.
Bill Burke will now cover some of the financial details, and then we will be glad to take your questions. Bill?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dave.As Dave noted, our businesses performed well in the quarter, meeting our earning's expectations and generating strong cash flows despite that difficult end market conditions. I will provide some of the financial highlights.In the quart
componenttext:
Thank you, Dave.
As Dave noted, our businesses performed well in the quarter, meeting our earning's expectations and generating strong cash flows despite that difficult end market conditions. I will provide some of the financial highlights.
In the quarter, selling, general and administrative expenses increased due to the recent acquisitions. The effective tax rate for the quarter was 27.5%, down slightly from last year's second quarter rate of 27.7%. For 2016, we expect our tax rate to be between 26% and 27%, as a result of the success of our ongoing tax planning initiatives. As we have said before, actual quarterly tax rates can differ dramatically, either positively or negatively, from this full year rate.
On the balance sheet, working capital, defined as receivables plus inventory less payables, was 19.8% of sales in the second quarter, down from 20.8% in the first quarter. Capital expenditures were $14 million in the quarter, and full year 2016 capital expenditures are expected to be $70 million.
Depreciation and amortization was $40 million -- $41 million for the quarter, and we expect full year depreciation and amortization to be $165 million.
Operating cash flow was very strong in the quarter at $189 million, up 16% over last year's second quarter. Free cash flow was also strong at $175 million in the quarter, up 15% over last year's second quarter. And as a percent of net income, free cash flow was 126% for the second quarter, and we expect the full year free cash flow to be 125% of net income.
Total debt was $2.14 billion at June 30, up approximately $200 million from the 2015 year-end. Offsetting this debt is cash and cash equivalents of $456 million, resulting in a net debt-to-capital ratio at June 30 of 33.4%. At June 30, we had approximately $1 billion of cash and credit facilities to fund our growth initiatives. We remain active on deploying our strong free cash flow, with our highest priority for capital deployment being acquisitions.
Subsequent to the end of the second quarter, we closed 2 acquisitions, HS Foils and Nu Instruments, bringing our cumulative expenditures for acquisitions in 2016 to approximately $360 million.
During the second quarter, we repurchased 417,000 shares of stock for $19 million. And as well on the first several days of July, we repurchased just under 1 million shares of stock for approximately $45 million.
In summary, we had a solid second quarter. We are well positioned to support our growth initiatives, with our strong balance sheet and cash flows.
Kevin?
