headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome, everyone, to the AMETEK Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I'd now like to turn the call over to your host, Kevin Coleman, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext: Welcome, everyone, to the AMETEK Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I'd now like to turn the call over to your host, Kevin Coleman, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you, Brent. Good morning, and thank you for joining us for AMETEK's Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call.-- I'm sorry, Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. With me this morning are Dave Zapico, Chief Executive Officer; and Bill Burke,
componenttext:
Great. Thank you, Brent. Good morning, and thank you for joining us for AMETEK's Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call.-- I'm sorry, Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. 
With me this morning are Dave Zapico, Chief Executive Officer; and Bill Burke, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
AMETEK's third quarter results were released earlier this morning. And are available electronically on market systems and on our website at the Investors section of ametek.com. 
This call is also webcasted. It can be accessed on our website and at streetevents.com. The call will be archived on both of these sites. 
Before we get started, I want to remind you that any statements made by AMETEK during the call that are not historical in nature are to be considered forward-looking statements. As such, these statements are subject to change based on various risk factors and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ significantly from expectations. A detailed discussion of the risks and uncertainties that may affect our future results is contained in AMETEK's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. AMETEK disclaims any intention or obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements. 
I'll also refer you to the Investors section of ametek.com for a reconciliation of any non-GAAP financial measures used during this call.  
We'll begin today with prepared remarks by Dave and Bill, and then we'll open it up for questions. I'll now turn the meeting over to Dave.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kevin, and good morning. AMETEK performed well in the third quarter with results in line with our expectations. We feel business conditions across our most challenging markets are beginning to stabilize. Although we remain cautious about the sh
componenttext:
Thank you, Kevin, and good morning. AMETEK performed well in the third quarter with results in line with our expectations. We feel business conditions across our most challenging markets are beginning to stabilize. Although we remain cautious about the short-term demand environment, we are encouraged with the stabilization. 
Also, I am pleased to announce that subsequent to the end of the third quarter, we acquired Laserage Technology, a provider of laser-based fabrication services for the medical device industry and an excellent fit with our engineered medical components business. 
With this acquisition, we have now acquired 5 businesses so far in 2016 and have deployed approximately $390 million in capital. We also deployed approximately $100 million on share repurchases during the third quarter. 
To support our capital deployment activities, we announced today that we entered into a private placement agreement to sell the equivalent of approximately $825 million in senior notes at attractive rates. We'll provide more detail on the recent acquisition and our private placement later. But at these activity shows, AMETEK remains committed to the discipline deployment of capital. 
Now let me provide a financial highlights for the quarter. Sales were in line with our expectations in the third quarter at $945 million, down 5% versus the third quarter of 2015. Organic sales were down 8% while acquisitions added 3%. The impact from foreign currency in the quarter was negligible. 
Operating income in the quarter was $201.1 million and operating income margin was 21.3%. Diluted earnings per share were $0.56, down 14% over last year's third quarter. 
Now turning to the individual operating groups. First, Electronic Instruments Group. Sales of $579.3 million were down 3% versus last year's third quarter. Organic sales were down 8% [ph], acquisitions contributed 5% and foreign currency was flat. 
The strong acquisition growth was driven by the contributions from the recent acquisitions of Brookfield, ESP/SurgeX, NU Instruments and HS Foils. The organic sales decline was driven in part by weakness across our oil and gas markets. Results for our oil and gas businesses were as expected, with conditions beginning to stabilize across each of our upstream, midstream and downstream businesses. 
EIG's operating income in the third quarter was $142.7 million, and operating income margins were 24.6%. 
The Electromechanical Group reported overall sales of $365.7 million, down 9% versus the third quarter of last year with organic sales down 7% and foreign currency at 1% headwind. The largest driver of the sales swing was our Engineered Materials, Interconnects and Packaging business. This business has also began to stabilize and expect to see similar conditions in the fourth quarter as we saw in the third quarter. 
EMG's operating income was $71.4 million in the quarter and operating margins were 19.5%. 
Now let me provide some background on the acquisition we announced this morning. Laserage is a leading provider of laser fabrication services to the medical device market. They offer precision to fabrication of minimally-invasive surgical devices, stents, specialty catheters and catheter-based delivery systems. They also have excellent design capabilities for medical devices. 
Laserage is an excellent addition to our growing presence in the medical industry. It is a great strategic fit with our engineered medical components business as it provides excellent market and technology synergies. 
In addition, the business operates in markets and applications with strong growth characteristics. Laserage were privately held. It's headquartered in Waukegan, Illinois, with a manufacturing facility in Milpitas, California. 
Laserage annual sales of $22 million. I would like to welcome the team from Laserage to AMETEK. 
We remain very active in identifying and executing highly strategic acquisitions across our businesses. The pipeline of acquisitions remains very solid and our teams continue to do an outstanding job supporting our M&A efforts. 
In addition to our continued focus on investing in strategic acquisitions, we continue to make investments to support long-term organic growth. 
In particular, we continue to make sizable investments in research, development and engineering and in 2016, we expect to invest $205 million or 5% of scales. I want to highlight just a few our recent new product introductions. 
Our Filetron Analytical business, a global leader in electric chemical and [indiscernible] spectroscopy for materials and mechanical research has added 4 new application-specific instruments to their abs XM series of laboratory instruments. The XM stands for extreme measurement and each new specific was developed with specific capabilities for highly targeted research applications. Each occupies less than half of footprint of similar laboratory instruments and provides increased measurement performance. These instruments are used for testing energy storage devices such as batteries, super capacitors and fuel cells as well as for testing materials used in solar and solar cell applications. 
AMETEK's Aerospace & Defense developed a patent pending exhaust gas thermocouple with a sheet made from an advanced ceramic matrix composite. The thermocouple is used to measure temperature and jet engine exhaust gases, and its highly advanced ceramic mode of heating extends the thermocouple's high temperature performance range. The heating material is 1/3 a stent of steel and nickel alloys exhibit better performance than pure ceramic materials and extends the life of the thermocouple having to postpone costly jet engine overhauls. 
Our Vision Research business, which is the leader in high-speed imaging systems, unveiled its new family of phantom VIO high-speed cameras. These compact rugged cameras are designed for a wide range of applications, including scientific analysis, material testing and defense research. The VIO family includes 8 individual models across 4 performance levels and 2 body styles providing users the flexibility for their specific needs. These high-speed, high-resolution cameras are packed full of features in a 5-inch cube that is designed for durability and can stand up to 100G performance. 
These investments in research and development combined with our strong engineering talent across the company are driving excellent new product development results. 
Revenue from new products introduced over the last 3 years, our vitality index was an excellent 25% in the quarter. 
We also remain focused on driving our Operational Excellence strategy. Our teams are doing an excellent job driving continued operational improvements through their businesses by leveraging our operational excellence performance token. 
Overall in 2016, we expect to generate $130 million in total Operational Excellence savings. These operational excellence activities include lean manufacturing, global sourcing and strategic procurement, value analysis and value engineering, design for Six Sigma and the movement of production to low cost, low [indiscernible]. These op ex initiatives also includes various tools that are focused on the front-end of our business. As I noted last quarter, we are focused on leveraging and broadening tools in this area across all of our businesses to ensure we are profitably positioned for long-term growth. 
Now I'll return for the outlook for the balance of the year. Our expectations remain unchanged for the year. We continue to expect 2016 revenue to be down low single digits on a percentage basis from 2015 with organic sales down mid-single-digit. We have tightened our guidance range for 2016 to a range of approximately $2.29 to $2.31 per diluted share even the midpoint of the guidance unchanged at $2.30. 
Fourth quarter 2016 sales are expected to be down low single digits versus the fourth quarter of 2015, with earnings of approximately $0.57 to $0.59 per diluted share. 
In summary, we delivered results that were in line with our expectations. We have reaffirmed our full year sales guidance and the midpoint of our earnings guidance. We have acquired 5 high-quality businesses in 2016 and our pipeline of acquisition opportunities is excellent. We generate strong free cash flow and has the balance sheet flexibility to continue to acquire businesses. We remain focused on aggressively managing our businesses in the short term while ensuring we make appropriate investments to properly position us for 2017 and beyond. We have a deep and talented management team that will continue to execute our 4 growth strategies. 
I'm very bullish on the future of AMETEK and believe we all are well positioned to drive meaningful earnings growth and shareholder returns moving forward. 
Bill Burke will now cover some of the financial details and provide more information on our private displacement. Then, we'll be glad to take your questions. Bill?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dave. As Dave noted, our business has performed well in the third quarter, with solid results that met our expectations. I'll provide some of the financial highlights. In the quarter, organic selling expenses were down roughly in line with or
componenttext:
Thank you, Dave. As Dave noted, our business has performed well in the third quarter, with solid results that met our expectations. I'll provide some of the financial highlights. 
In the quarter, organic selling expenses were down roughly in line with organic sales on a percentage basis. General and administrative expenses were up over last year's third quarter on higher consultant costs. The effective tax rate for the quarter was 25%, down from last year's rate of 26.1%. We continue to expect our tax rate for 2016 to be between 26% and 27%. As we've said before, actual quarterly tax rates can differ dramatically, either positively or negatively from this full year rate. 
Working capital defined as receivables plus inventory less payables, was 20.8% of sales in the third quarter. Capital expenditures were $15 million for the quarter, and we expect full year capital expenditures to be approximately $70 million. 
Depreciation and amortization expense in the quarter was $42 million, and for the full year, we expect depreciation and amortization to be approximately $165 million. 
Operating cash flow was $169 million in the quarter, and free cash flow was $154 million, representing 118% of net income. For the full year, we expect free cash flow to be a strong 125% of net income. 
We've been very active deploying our free cash flow this year. In the third quarter, we deployed approximately $65 million on the acquisition of the NU Instruments and HS Foils and subsequent to the end of the quarter, we deployed approximately $32 million on the acquisition of Laserage. 
These acquisitions form our cumulative expenditures for acquisitions in 2016 to approximately $390 million. 
In addition, during the third quarter, we repurchased 2.2 million shares of our stock for approximately $100 million. 
The highest priority for our cash flow remains acquisitions. However, as we have shown, we will look to opportunistically deploy our cash flow and share buybacks. 
Total debt at September 30 was $2.15 billion, up approximately $200 million from the 2015 year-end. 
Offsetting this debt is cash and cash equivalents of $445 million, resulting in a net debt to capital ratio at September 30 of 34%. 
At September 30, we had approximately $1 billion of cash and credit facilities to fund our growth initiatives. 
As we announced this morning, we entered into a private placement on October 31 to sell the equivalent of approximately $825 million in senior notes. We are issuing EUR 500 million and GBP 225 million, all with maturities ranging from 10 to 15 years. The proceeds of this offering will be used to pay down our revolver balance and to repay a GBP 40 million note due later this month. 
The private placement was well received by our lenders. Overall, decision had a weighted average interest rate of 1.82% and a weighted average maturity of 11.5 years. This offering provides AMETEK with a larger financing capacity and increased flexibility to support our growth initiatives. 
In summary, our business is managed very well in the third quarter in the face of challenging market conditions. We remain active in deploying capital and are well positioned to support our growth initiatives with our strong balance sheet and cash flows. Kevin?

componenttext: Could you just talk about the tone of sales as the third quarter progress? And maybe give us kind of same on order rates may be also tell us the organic order rate change in the quarter.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, sure, Scott. I'll start with sales. I mean, overall, sales came in in line with our expectations. As we said, we'd be down mid-single digits, and we were down 5%. And so it's right on. Organic sales were down close to 7.5%, which is very close to ou
componenttext: Sure, sure, Scott. I'll start with sales. I mean, overall, sales came in in line with our expectations. As we said, we'd be down mid-single digits, and we were down 5%. And so it's right on. Organic sales were down close to 7.5%, which is very close to our expectations. We did see some weaker growth in our Aerospace segment, mainly because of the business of regional jet markets slowed a bit, but it a bit stronger growth in our Ultra Precision Technologies business. So when you look at the whole picture during Q3 have played out largely as we expected. If you recall, we get a deep dive at the end of the second quarter to reforecast, and it turned out exactly as we thought. In terms of orders, the organic order rates in the quarter were minus 3.5%. So the organic sales were down 8%, so we got some momentum. Book-to-bill was 1.02 and the orders trended up in the quarter. So we're feeling good going into Q4.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very good. And that typical analysis that Frank did and then you kind of jumped in on as quarter-to-date would you mind doing that sort of the division of analysis?
componenttext: Very good. And that typical analysis that Frank did and then you kind of jumped in on as quarter-to-date would you mind doing that sort of the division of analysis?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, Scott. Overall, aerospace sales were down mid-single digits in the quarter. We continue to see strong growth on our converged well OEM business. We won excellent content across a wide number of next-generation commercial aircraft platforms and
componenttext: Yes, sure, Scott. Overall, aerospace sales were down mid-single digits in the quarter. We continue to see strong growth on our converged well OEM business. We won excellent content across a wide number of next-generation commercial aircraft platforms and we're really well positioned to benefit from the discontinued growth. Our business in regional jet business continues to be weak and the military was down a bit in a quarter due to program timing. So for all of 2016, we expect aerospace sales to be down low single digits, saw the growth in our commercial OEM business offset largely by weakness in the business of regional jet. I'm jumping into the process segment, organic sales in process were down mid-single digits in the quarter. This was in line with our expectations and driven by weakness across our oil and gas businesses. We did see stabilization with our oil and gas businesses during the quarter as we expected, and we expect stabilization to continue through the fourth quarter. Our Ultra Precision Technologies, our UPT, business, again, had a very strong quarter, with good growth across our businesses and as a result of the new product rollouts and global and new market financial initiatives, it was a very positive quarter. For all of 2016, we continue to expect organic sales for our process businesses to be down mid-to high single digits, driven largely by oil and gas. Our sales for our power and industrial businesses were up mid-single digits in the quarter, driven by the contributions from acquisitions, ESP/SurgeX and Brookfield. Organic sales were down low double digits in the quarter, driven by a difficult prior year comparison. And for all of 2016, we expect organic sales for power industrial to be down mid-single digits versus 2015, which is unchanged from our prior forecast. Organic sales who differentiated EMG businesses were down and single digits, driven largely by weakness across our engineered material interconnects and packaging business. We are starting to see stabilization in this business also as expected like oil and gas. For all our differentiated EMG, we continue to expect organic sales to be down mid-single digits versus the prior year. For care and specialty motors, the last segment, smallest segments, organic sales were down high single digits in the third quarter, driven by softer demand across key markets and for all of 2016, we expect sales for this business to be down mid-single digits organically, unchanged from the previous expectations. When you look at it from the group level, for all of our EIG is unchanged from prior guidance we provided last quarter. We continue to expect overall sales to be down both single digits with both organic sales down mid-single digits due to the same for EMG, it's the same as prior guidance we provided last quarter, with both overall and organic sales down mid-single digits. And for all of AMETEK, our guidance remains unchanged, with overall sales expected to be down low single digits and organic sales down mid-single digits.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Matt Summerville with Alembic Global Advisors.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple follow ups. On the oil and gas side of things, can you size that business for us today in terms of where you think it comes in overall for 2016? And not just in EIG, but also if you want to call it kind of your collateral exposure that you h
componenttext: Just a couple follow ups. On the oil and gas side of things, can you size that business for us today in terms of where you think it comes in overall for 2016? And not just in EIG, but also if you want to call it kind of your collateral exposure that you have in other parts of the businesses. And then are you able to put some numbers around the point that you're making that you seeing stabilization. Can you kind of walk us through how that business is maybe progress to get you to that conclusion?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, right. Yes, I'll start with -- entering the year, the oil and gas prices for AMETEK was about $360 million, and that was -- that's across our entire business. The majority of that is in electronic instruments, so our process segment. As they are pl
componenttext: Right, right. Yes, I'll start with -- entering the year, the oil and gas prices for AMETEK was about $360 million, and that was -- that's across our entire business. The majority of that is in electronic instruments, so our process segment. As they are played out, that business is going to be down about 33% or down about $120 million. That's 60% decline in our upstream business and 60% decline in our mid and downstream businesses. So if you go back at the peak, your upstream sales are down about 70% tied to the rig count decline in our midstream and downstream businesses are down about 20%, driven by cost of capital spending and delayed maintenance work. So we saw that the peak in 2014, we saw an initial decline in our upstream business. We got into 2015, we saw an initial decline in our upstream business. In 2016, we saw a continuing decline in the upstream, and then falling through the midstream. We went down up about 1/3 again about $240 million coming out of 2016. When we look at it, what I feel good about it when I look at the order rates. I mean, the order rates for our businesses are supporting a flat Q4 largely in the -- I'd say, kind of longer backlog business with some short term MRO business, but I feel good about the backlog we have entering the quarter. When I think about the beginning of the year, we were down large percentages in oil and gas, 35% in Q1, about the same in Q2. In Q3, we're down about 20%, and we think that will continue to wear down even less in Q4. So the sequential run rate in the business definitely have stabilized, our order rates stabilized and I think we took a good look at it at the end of Q2, and it feels the same right now.

componenttextpreview: Yes, we haven't done our planning for 2017 yet, so we're not going to have much guidance on that. But I think what we're seeing is rig counts have started to pick up. Activity is beginning. The market is starting to come back in equilibrium. That will con
componenttext: Yes, we haven't done our planning for 2017 yet, so we're not going to have much guidance on that. But I think what we're seeing is rig counts have started to pick up. Activity is beginning. The market is starting to come back in equilibrium. That will continue through 2017. Certainly, in 2017, we aren't going to set the same headwinds that we had this year, and we're going to set down with our business during our budgeting cycle and all of our businesses during our budgeting cycle, during the next few weeks in getting real good feel for what's going on and where to communicate that guidance to you in our Q4 earnings call. But it really played out as expected. And going into next year, we'll find out, but we certainly aren't going to expect the headwinds that.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Great. l guess, some last -- I mean, is there certain lag effect that we should expect for you guys traditional historically -- I mean, what have you experienced when you come out of something like that [indiscernible]?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think there is -- you really have a situation where there is excess capacity built up in the history. And that excess capacity has to be utilized. So there may be a bit of -- if you look at our upstream business, that business typically long term f
componenttext: Yes, I think there is -- you really have a situation where there is excess capacity built up in the history. And that excess capacity has to be utilized. So there may be a bit of -- if you look at our upstream business, that business typically long term follows the Baker Hughes drilling rig index, but it doesn't fall directly. Usually the rigging index ticks up and then we'll follow as capacity. So there could be a lag, but when I think during 2017, that will play out. So again, we're going to get detailed insight from our businesses, but one thing that we're sure of is that any small increase on organic growth, we've leaned the cost structure these businesses out. These businesses are very well managed, they have strong market positions, higher market share in oil and gas businesses, and we're poised to capitalize on any market growth and returns, but we're not forecasting any right now.

componenttextpreview: So just on the geographic, if you can give the growth in different geographics around the world. And especially, can you remind us how much BRIC is for AMETEK in terms of sales and how those regions actually performed in the quarter?
componenttext: So just on the geographic, if you can give the growth in different geographics around the world. And especially, can you remind us how much BRIC is for AMETEK in terms of sales and how those regions actually performed in the quarter?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, sure. I'm glad to do that. I'll start with the U.S. We were down low double digits versus the prior year, and it was driven by broad industrial weakness, but the key factor that's driving negative growth were oil and gas and metals. And if you look
componenttext: Sure, sure. I'm glad to do that. I'll start with the U.S. We were down low double digits versus the prior year, and it was driven by broad industrial weakness, but the key factor that's driving negative growth were oil and gas and metals. And if you look at our trend, it's really been that way for the last 3 quarters. We've had about low double-digit, 10% decline the last 3 quarters, so it's stabilized at that level. If we jump over to Europe, it was down low single digits in line with recent trends there. We've been down low single digits for the better part of the year. Asia was the one positive. It was up 1% organically. That was -- if you think back over the past year, 1, 1.5 years, it was down low double digits, and down low double digits, down 10% down mid-single digits, so [indiscernible] quarters, now it's up 1%. And China, the biggest driver in Asia, was down slightly, so down about 1%. So we feel pretty good about Asia. We had good performance in Japan, in Korea and some other markets, so it was up 1% organically. When you go to the BRIC countries, overall, the BRIC countries are 11% of sales. We've been very successful historically in the BRIC countries, but the emerging markets are challenged right now. Our emerging market exposure is dominated by China, it's the largest, by far. And as I already mentioned, we were down about 1%. But when you look at places like Brazil and Russia, they were down very significant double digits, 20%-plus in each of those markets. And India has been a different story, it's been growing at mid single-digit rate. This quarter, it was a little different, it was down a bit, about 20%, but that's more from large program orders. We don't really have a base business in India yet. It will bounce around, but I really see that trend continuing. So basically in BRIC countries, we have China stabilized, that's the biggest market. India on a slow growth path and Brazil and Russia in the dumps.

componenttext: Yes, I'll go through the whole order profile. We booked about 964 million orders in the quarter. The total orders were down 2%. As I mentioned earlier to Scott, the organic orders were down 3.5%. EIG organic orders were down 5% and EMG organic orders were down 1%.

componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. And lastly on the business. I know you said that the business has stabilized quarter-to-quarter, and you now, can you give us some insights into the destocking that you had seen over the last 3 quarters in that business especially in the met
componenttext: Okay, got it. And lastly on the business. I know you said that the business has stabilized quarter-to-quarter, and you now, can you give us some insights into the destocking that you had seen over the last 3 quarters in that business especially in the metal side. How that's progressing and where we are with that?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We continue to expect sales will be down roughly $125 million, about 25% in 2016. But the year-over-year declines will moderate in Q4 due to easier comps, so we're stabilization begin in the market. The pricing trends, we talked about pricing transfe
componenttext: Yes. We continue to expect sales will be down roughly $125 million, about 25% in 2016. But the year-over-year declines will moderate in Q4 due to easier comps, so we're stabilization begin in the market. The pricing trends, we talked about pricing transfer key metals we have exposure to our mix with some increasing like nickel and vanadium over the last quarter and some decreasing like molybdenum and titanium, so that's mixed. As I mentioned last quarter and to your point, our visibility into inventory levels within this market, this channel is limited, but it's largely playing out as expected. We're seeing order rate -- orders coming from inventory, depleted businesses, customers, and we're not seeing orders in other places where the inventory is still there. So we're not saying that inventory destocking is complete, but we're seeing up order rates to be comfortable. Our fourth quarter is going to be a lot like our third, and that's our forecast statement.

componenttext: Okay, just wanted to come back to the comments regarding business stabilization. It sounds like the optics of the easing comps is helping that narrative. Are you seeing an actual fundamental inflection in that tone in those businesses? Or is it more element comparisons? And then any early view on 2017 expectations as you see some of these headwinds abate?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The first point is, you're correct, we are seeing easier comps as we progress through the year. But in our last call, we spend a lot of time comparing the second half of the year to the first half of the year. And they were essentially carbon copies
componenttext: Yes. The first point is, you're correct, we are seeing easier comps as we progress through the year. But in our last call, we spend a lot of time comparing the second half of the year to the first half of the year. And they were essentially carbon copies of each other. So, along with easier comps, the business has stabilized because the second half of the year we're going to be very similar to the volume and profitability that we did in the first half. Regarding 2017, I'm just not going to give guidance right now. We typically don't give it until we release our fourth quarter earnings. We have a very full some budget process. Bill and I sit down with each of our business, and we have a very detailed process to to work through. Certainly, we're not expecting a major change in the global macro environment. We'll be focus on driving cost reductions to our Operational Excellence activities, but we're not going comment on it until we get to the fourth quarter earnings.

componenttext: Okay. And then just with regards to the private placement offering, how they get a smart transaction there. Do you expect an interest savings? And then, I guess, as you look at available cash and free cash flow generation and the new capacity it provides, how should we think about that over the capacity over the next 12 months with this new arrangement?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think from -- this is Bill Burke. I think from an interest rate perspective, certainly, the rate that we're talking about is very close to the revolver that we're paying, which is about 1.7% before any Fed actions. So I think it's pretty much a was
componenttext: Yes, I think from -- this is Bill Burke. I think from an interest rate perspective, certainly, the rate that we're talking about is very close to the revolver that we're paying, which is about 1.7% before any Fed actions. So I think it's pretty much a wash from that perspective it. But what it really does it gives us a lot of capacity to after in terms of capital deployment and particularly going after acquisitions. So I think it's really just a retooling of that capacity and if you think about it, we took short term debt and put it out for 11.5 years at essentially the same interest rates. So it was a no-brainer from that perspective. I think most importantly, it also gives us the capacity to continue our capital deployment.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And would you be able to may be size that, that incremental capacity that it does provide?
componenttext: And would you be able to may be size that, that incremental capacity that it does provide?

componenttext: Sure. We have with cash and unused revolver overcapacity, we have approximately $1.5 billion of firepower to go on acquisitions. So we're pretty pleased with that. We have a strong balance sheet, and we're looking to deploy it. We have a great pipeline of deals, and we're aggressively working a lot of them.

componenttext: There is a ramp of our sales from 3Q to 4Q, as you mentioned. We typically see a sequential ramp from quarter [indiscernible] quarter 3. The places where our business seasonality plays out are our Process business is, and we're seeing order entry rates in the case that, that's going to happen a little bit of our power businesses has a bit of seasonality. So when you look across our portfolio, we have businesses that have a bit of seasonality. It's built into the forecast. And as I mentioned last quarter, our Q4 is a lot like our Q2, so we don't have anything heroic forecasted just a typical sequential ramp up due to seasonality.

componenttext: I think so. I mean,, I'll point you to our organic order rates. Our organic sales in Q3 were, as I said, down about 7.5% and our orders were down about 3.5%. And we have a little ramp to get through, but it's very similar to what we did in Q2.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you think about our narrative, our first half of the year was much like our second half of the year, so it's kind of flattened out. So there aren't big comparison benefits that we'll see going into next year. Now certainly we won't see the oil and gas
componenttext: If you think about our narrative, our first half of the year was much like our second half of the year, so it's kind of flattened out. So there aren't big comparison benefits that we'll see going into next year. Now certainly we won't see the oil and gas headwinds, we don't expect to see the headwinds in the metals business, so those will be better. But it's not like we're entering next year with a bunch of easy comps. The businesses flattened out, we're glad it flattened out, we've got our hands around it and now we're focused on our budget and profit improvement that we're going to get in 2017 is going to come from what we learned those budget meetings, it's going to come from our Operational Excellence activities, and it's going to come from M&A.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Nigel Coe with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So  on the timing of the product placements, sounds like it's more driven by the Fed likely to go Fed goes in December revolver rate goes up. Is that right? So more an indication of your confidence in the deployment of capital?
componenttext: So  on the timing of the product placements, sounds like it's more driven by the Fed likely to go Fed goes in December revolver rate goes up. Is that right? So more an indication of your confidence in the deployment of capital?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it wasn't -- that wasn't the primary driver, that may happen, but as Bill said, it was a no-brainer. We had revolver debt, that short-term rates that we could term out until 11.5 years and have a very, very small interest rate change. So that was the
componenttext: Yes, it wasn't -- that wasn't the primary driver, that may happen, but as Bill said, it was a no-brainer. We had revolver debt, that short-term rates that we could term out until 11.5 years and have a very, very small interest rate change. So that was the primary reason, but we do have confidence that we're going to be able to deploy that capital. We have -- we're well positioned, I think, in our acquisition world right now. We remain as the primary use of our cash flow with core competency and key driver of long-term value. We have disciplined processes around our foreseeing, around our diligence, around our integration. We told you that we've added capacity and [indiscernible] made some changes in sourcing new deals an expanded our pipeline to slightly larger businesses while leading our bread-and-butter deals in the $50 million to $250 million range. The acquisition environment is very tough. We're getting deals done. We've got 5 deals done this year, deployed $390 million in capital and the year is not over. Pipeline is very good. It appears to have ticked up a bit and the private placement fees are right into that because. We have about $1.5 billion in cash and unused paper and revolver. So we're feeling really good about being able to deploy the capital, and we're feeling really good about the opportunities also.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, long-term debt at 1.7% is no-brainer. But we are seeing more large deals getting done in [indiscernible].
componenttext: Sure. I mean, long-term debt at 1.7% is no-brainer. But we are seeing more large deals getting done in [indiscernible].

componenttext: Actually Nigel it was 1.82%. 1.7% was what our revolver debt is now. We termed it out at 1.82%.

componenttext: Okay, but we are seeing larger deals getting announced in product markets so I'm wondering if the texture of your M&A backlog is changing and whether we're seeing in the mix towards more larger opportunities?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we expanded our pipeline of opportunities to include businesses in the revenue of $500 million. So certainly, those deals are working a way to the pipeline. So in terms of mix, there is a larger mix of bigger businesses, but that doesn't change the f
componenttext: Yes, we expanded our pipeline of opportunities to include businesses in the revenue of $500 million. So certainly, those deals are working a way to the pipeline. So in terms of mix, there is a larger mix of bigger businesses, but that doesn't change the fundamental bread-and-butter of the business to $50 million, to $100 million, to $200 million deal. And I think the backlog that we're seeing right now is a healthy mix of the $50 million, $100 million, $200 million deals and a couple of bigger deals we're looking at. we're very active right now, and we don't have anything for sure definitely, but we're spending a lot of time and effort evaluating these opportunities, and we have the balance sheet to execute on.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: No question. And quick on pricing. Any change in the pricing environments by business?

componenttextpreview: No, it's about the same. We got about 1.2% of price during the quarter. Largely it's playing out the same as the prior quarter where the oil and gas market, the metals market or the pricing is more difficult. But overall, we're getting positive price.
componenttext: No, it's about the same. We got about 1.2% of price during the quarter. Largely it's playing out the same as the prior quarter where the oil and gas market, the metals market or the pricing is more difficult. But overall, we're getting positive price.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Robert McCarthy with Stifel.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robert McCarthy with Stifel.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess, we didn't have the cuts for '16, so that's good. And I guess, there's not just going to be much about '17 and there's been a lot of questions asked. Just expanding on Nigel's comment about price. Can you talk a little bit about kind of the
componenttext: Well, I guess, we didn't have the cuts for '16, so that's good. And I guess, there's not just going to be much about '17 and there's been a lot of questions asked. Just expanding on Nigel's comment about price. Can you talk a little bit about kind of the pricing environment this year versus previous years. And what would be your expectation if we did see kind of an uptick in any of the material inflation or better pricing environment? Where will be for your margins going forward?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Because of our strong niche market positions, I definitely feel that we have pricing power in our business. What you saw this year is a lot of migration to lower capability products within our portfolio. So instead of buying the high-end product that
componenttext: Yes. Because of our strong niche market positions, I definitely feel that we have pricing power in our business. What you saw this year is a lot of migration to lower capability products within our portfolio. So instead of buying the high-end product that can do just about everything with all the bell and whistles, the customers migrated to more basic functionality. And that's really happened in the last downturn back in 2009 also. So we expect this, along with that price effect, we have -- which has been very difficult in the markets that are under duress that we talked a lot about like oil and gas and metals, you'll also have a mix effect that where people are buying down the product line. So those will be the 2 big factors that I will see. And I think as the market stabilizes, we'll see slow migration back up to the high end of the portfolio and we expect to get positive price. Our pricing was greater than total inflation in the business by a bit in the quarter, so we've been able to offset our total inflation, and it's not a good pricing environment. If I look back a couple of years, we were getting 2 points a price, so it's definitely down about where pricing in excess of inflation and I think that will improve as the general economic global level, macroeconomic trends improved.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, obviously slow macro environment does great opportunity perhaps increase focus on global excellence, increase organic improvement in the business may be some restructuring. How are you thinking about that going into '17 from a planning persp
componenttext: Well, I mean, obviously slow macro environment does great opportunity perhaps increase focus on global excellence, increase organic improvement in the business may be some restructuring. How are you thinking about that going into '17 from a planning perspective in terms of -- if you're in a slow macro environment, what levers can you really full year to drive longer-term value in '18 and beyond?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. See in 2015, we did quite a lot up restructuring. We had 2 restructurings and we just completed them recently. And as we look through our businesses through those budgeting process, we're going to look at all the tools we have, low-cost production,
componenttext: Right. See in 2015, we did quite a lot up restructuring. We had 2 restructurings and we just completed them recently. And as we look through our businesses through those budgeting process, we're going to look at all the tools we have, low-cost production, sourcing, remanufacturing, all the tools in that AMETEK tools kit. And I feel comfortable this year we had $130 million in cost reductions from the restructuring and the cost reductions and I feel confident that we'll have another healthy number going into 2017. But I'm going to wait to comment on that because I have to get through the budgeting process, and we have to look at what each of our businesses plans on doing.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Andrew Obin with Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Andrew Obin with Bank of America.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question, looking where you're able to do your private placement, seems like the rate are quite attractive. As we're sitting at the bottom for interest rates, does that change your view on how much of -- what kind of multiples you can payout for de
componenttext: Just a question, looking where you're able to do your private placement, seems like the rate are quite attractive. As we're sitting at the bottom for interest rates, does that change your view on how much of -- what kind of multiples you can payout for deals given just how attractive financing is? Because historically, you guys have been an absolute return company, and what we see is that the company is liable to deals in this environment more of the spread approach. Are you reconsidering that?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, not reconsidering that, Andrew. We're still an absolute return company. I think the key metric for us is our return on invested capital in year 3. That number has been 10% for quite a long time, and it's still 10%, and that means we have to parse the
componenttext: No, not reconsidering that, Andrew. We're still an absolute return company. I think the key metric for us is our return on invested capital in year 3. That number has been 10% for quite a long time, and it's still 10%, and that means we have to parse the deals that we're looking at, and we need a strong viable pipeline, which we have now to find the deals that we can get the hurdle rate to 10% ROIC in year 3. So we have not taken a relative approach on pricing. It's still absolute, and returns in pricing on deals, and the pipeline that we have is better than it has been in the past, and I feel positive that will be able to deploy the cash and unused revolver capacity to get some deal done moving forward. Now we can't predict when deals will happen in any quarter because we have to finish our diligence and have get to get through a lot of things, but we got a lot of activity going on and our teams are active and working many processes, so I'm optimistic that some of that will turn into positive, and we'll be able to deploy some of our cash.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just a follow-up on your markets. Historically, you described your portfolio, the bulk of it was very steady and part of it was doing well, a part of it was not doing well. Within the products that's doing steady, what parts of the business are you pa
componenttext: And just a follow-up on your markets. Historically, you described your portfolio, the bulk of it was very steady and part of it was doing well, a part of it was not doing well. Within the products that's doing steady, what parts of the business are you paying attention to going to 2017 with potential inflection points?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Andrew. I'm going to come back to the same comment about working through our budgets, but I will comment that our metrology businesses are doing well, our UPT businesses are doing well. The exposure we have to the medical market is doing well. The co
componenttext: Yes, Andrew. I'm going to come back to the same comment about working through our budgets, but I will comment that our metrology businesses are doing well, our UPT businesses are doing well. The exposure we have to the medical market is doing well. The commercial aerospace market, our OEM commercial aerospace sales are strong, and we don't see an ending to that. So I pointed those for positives and a lot of our other markets are flat to down a bit and they're dealing with the same slow growth macro conditions and the same that all businesses are doing.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Christian Marco with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Christian Marco with Cowen and Company.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you consider yourself to be a more cyclical company now than it would have past maybe before prices made their big decline?
componenttext: Do you consider yourself to be a more cyclical company now than it would have past maybe before prices made their big decline?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I believe that just about all markets cycling on the long run. And we do have cyclical closer in our portfolio, 20% of our business is down nearly 30%, and we've talked about that. And when you think about AMETEK, our strategy is to focus on a broad diver
componenttext: I believe that just about all markets cycling on the long run. And we do have cyclical closer in our portfolio, 20% of our business is down nearly 30%, and we've talked about that. And when you think about AMETEK, our strategy is to focus on a broad diverse set of niche market and to look to grow and expand in this market, both organically and through M&A. So we don't want to be overexposed in any one single market. In fact, we have the same philosophy of any one single customer or any single technology, so we'll look to continue that balance. We don't have exposure to some of the markets, in which have been growing recently like the construction markets, not residential construction or residential construction. We don't have a big exposure to consumer market. We have a limited exposure to the auto market. All these markets are cyclical as well, but they're doing well right now and will cycle down at some point in the future. So the way I look at it, we weathered the worst of the cyclical markets downturns in oil and gas and metals. Our cost structure has cleaned out. Our businesses remained well positioned in their niches, we have excellent niche positions. So we're very optimistic we're going to see sizable profit improvement when the market returns.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then I think you mentioned your [indiscernible] using excess gas in your prepared remarks. And I was wondering if you could use that ceramic protection in other application, I don't know, maybe in 5 years in refineries or any such applications?
componenttext: Great. And then I think you mentioned your [indiscernible] using excess gas in your prepared remarks. And I was wondering if you could use that ceramic protection in other application, I don't know, maybe in 5 years in refineries or any such applications?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's possible to use the material in other applications. Certainly, the right spot is an exhaust gas thermocouple because they're right in the high temperature exhaust gases and if you have a thermocouple that can -- your multiple use on every aircra
componenttext: Yes, it's possible to use the material in other applications. Certainly, the right spot is an exhaust gas thermocouple because they're right in the high temperature exhaust gases and if you have a thermocouple that can -- your multiple use on every aircraft engine and if you can get your thermocouple to last a bit longer and allow the airlines to fly the planes a bit longer, that adds value and that's the application that we're focused on right now and we're very optimistic about it.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Christopher Glynn with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Christopher Glynn with Oppenheimer.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry to get another bite of the apple here. The mix is a big margin headwind this year, presumably a lack of mix next year. So relative to the organic headwinds this year, assuming more neutral next year, what does that mean to lose that mix headwind? Ho
componenttext: Sorry to get another bite of the apple here. The mix is a big margin headwind this year, presumably a lack of mix next year. So relative to the organic headwinds this year, assuming more neutral next year, what does that mean to lose that mix headwind? How much of that hurt you this year, do you think?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the mix has been a substantial issue. One of the components of our margin decline. The biggest issue has been the drop in organic growth rates has been cleared and there's the mix effect also. And we didn't get the pricing that we like this
componenttext: Well, I think the mix has been a substantial issue. One of the components of our margin decline. The biggest issue has been the drop in organic growth rates has been cleared and there's the mix effect also. And we didn't get the pricing that we like this year. So all that is going to the mix of ferrying how next year looks, but I don't think that -- it really depends on the overall global economic environment. And I can't predict an improvement in mix at this point, but I understand your point. You think it could get better, but I'm really not saying at this point until I've gone through budgets with our folks.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Graham with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Graham with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick one for me also, although the answer is probably longer than the question. Dave, as you are going through the budget process for 2017, obviously, you're going to tend very carefully to the organic situation, which it does not look like your o
componenttext: Just a quick one for me also, although the answer is probably longer than the question. Dave, as you are going through the budget process for 2017, obviously, you're going to tend very carefully to the organic situation, which it does not look like your organic sales have declined more than your end markets have, particularly in the 2 businesses that have been problematic. But I think historically, the view has been that because of the types of businesses that you're in, that they would not decline as much as the end market. That does not seem to be the case, so really 2 question stem from that. Number one, what is the plan for those businesses to sort of make them outperforms in their market? And then secondly, as you approach organic in the other businesses, is there more of a portfolio change that might be needed more towards the faster-growing businesses and market that you purchased in recent years and maybe away from some of the more basic industrial ones that you kind of took with you from last decade?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's a lot of questions there, Scott. We'll start with the last question first. As I mentioned before, our strategy is to plan a broad set of diverse niche markets and we love to grow and expand these niches. And really the diversification is a ke
componenttext: Yes, there's a lot of questions there, Scott. We'll start with the last question first. As I mentioned before, our strategy is to plan a broad set of diverse niche markets and we love to grow and expand these niches. And really the diversification is a key point. We don't want to get overexposed in any one single market. And even though we've had tremendous headwinds in oil and gas metals market, we're still very profitable company. Some of the best margins in the industrial space. So that the diversity is serving as well there. When you think about the parts of our portfolio that were doing well I mentioned our UPT business, I mentioned the medical space, I mentioned commercial OEM aerospace, those are in the acquisition queue with all of the other business. So we like to acquire more businesses in those areas for sure. When you answer the first part of your question saying, in actually pleased with the performance of our businesses and the cyclical markets, the oil and gas and metals business, we've leaned out the cost structures, those are excellent businesses with excellent niche positions, and I'm not sure of how the organic growth is gone to play out, but I can tell you, when it comes back, we're going to make a lot of money because those cost structures are leaned out. Regarding the organic growth of the company, I mentioned last quarter that we want to focus on the organic growth and making sure we're getting our fair share of the business and really focus in the front-end of the business and get as good in our sales and marketing functions as we earn our operational functions. So we need our customer facing capabilities to equal our strong operational capabilities, and we're working on that by looking at best practices and tools around our company and doing the same thing we did in the operations of applying them through our entire business. So we're focusing on key initiatives in that area, and that's largely driven from the fact that the next 5 years we might not be able to -- if you think back from 2005 to 2015, AMETEK grew 3% compounded annual growth rate and organic growth. We grew 8% in M&A, so 11% top line, and we've got 16% compound annual growth and EPS to the bottom line. If you want to continue that over the next few years, the next 5 years, which we clearly do, we're just going to take some average to work on organic growth across the company to make sure that we can outperform in that area. We're not talking about a meaningful change, not a needle mover long term. Certainly, not a benefit in 2017. But in 2018, I hope we'll see some benefits of some slightly better organic growth.

Welcome, everyone, to the AMETEK Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] 
I'd now like to turn the call over to your host, Kevin Coleman, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you, Brent. Good morning, and thank you for joining us for AMETEK's second quarter earnings conference call -- I'm sorry, third quarter earnings conference call. With me this morning are Dave Zapico, Chief Executive Officer; and Bill Burke,
componenttext:
Great. Thank you, Brent. Good morning, and thank you for joining us for AMETEK's second quarter earnings conference call -- I'm sorry, third quarter earnings conference call. 
With me this morning are Dave Zapico, Chief Executive Officer; and Bill Burke, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
AMETEK's third quarter results were released earlier this morning and are available electronically on market systems and on our website at the Investors section of ametek.com. 
This call is also webcasted. It can be accessed on our website and at streetevents.com. The call will be archived on both of these sites. 
Before we get started, I want to remind you that any statements made by AMETEK during the call that are not historical in nature are to be considered forward-looking statements. As such, these statements are subject to change based on various risk factors and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ significantly from expectations. A detailed discussion of the risk and uncertainties that may affect our future results is contained in AMETEK's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. AMETEK disclaims any intention or obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements. 
I'll also refer you to the Investors section of ametek.com for a reconciliation of any non-GAAP financial measures used during this conference call.  
We'll begin today with prepared remarks by Dave and Bill, and then we'll open it up for questions. 
I'll now turn the meeting over to Dave.

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kevin, and good morning. AMETEK performed well in the third quarter, with results in line with our expectations. We feel business conditions across our most challenging markets are beginning to stabilize. Although we remain cautious about the s
componenttext:
Thank you, Kevin, and good morning. AMETEK performed well in the third quarter, with results in line with our expectations. We feel business conditions across our most challenging markets are beginning to stabilize. Although we remain cautious about the short-term demand environment, we are encouraged with this stabilization. 
Also, I am pleased to announce that subsequent to the end of the third quarter, we acquired Laserage Technology, a provider of laser-based fabrication services for the medical device industry, and an excellent fit with our engineered medical components business. 
With this acquisition, we have now acquired 5 businesses so far in 2016 and have deployed approximately $390 million in capital. We also deployed approximately $100 million on share repurchases during our third quarter. 
To support our capital deployment activities, we announced today that we entered into a private placement agreement to sell the equivalent of approximately $825 million in senior notes at attractive rates. We'll provide more detail on the recent acquisition and our private placement later. But as these activities show, AMETEK remains committed to the disciplined deployment of capital. 
Now let me provide the financial highlights for the quarter. Sales were in line with our expectations in the third quarter at $945 million, down 5% versus the third quarter of 2015. Organic sales were down 8% while acquisitions added 3%. The impact from foreign currency in the quarter was negligible. 
Operating income in the quarter was $201.1 million and operating income margin was 21.3%. Diluted earnings per share were $0.56, down 14% over last year's third quarter. 
Now turning to the individual operating groups. First, Electronic Instruments Group. Sales of $579.3 million were down 3% versus last year's third quarter. Organic sales were down 8%, acquisitions contributed 5% and foreign currency was flat. 
The strong acquisition growth was driven by the contributions from the recent acquisitions of Brookfield, ESP/SurgeX, Nu Instruments and HS Foils. The organic sales decline was driven in part by weakness across our oil and gas markets. Results for our oil and gas businesses were as expected, with conditions beginning to stabilize across each of our upstream, midstream and downstream businesses. 
EIG's operating income in the third quarter was $142.7 million, and operating income margins were 24.6%. 
The Electromechanical Group reported overall sales of $365.7 million, down 9% versus the third quarter of last year, with organic sales down 7%, and foreign currency at 1% headwind. The largest driver of the sales weakness was our Engineered Materials, Interconnects and Packaging business. This business has also began to stabilize, and we expect to see similar conditions in the fourth quarter as we saw in the third quarter. 
EMG's operating income was $71.4 million in the quarter and operating margins were 19.5%. 
Now let me provide some background on the acquisition we announced this morning. Laserage is a leading provider of laser fabrication services to the medical device market. They offer precision tube fabrication of minimally-invasive surgical devices, stents, specialty catheters and catheter-based delivery systems. They also have excellent design capabilities for medical devices. 
Laserage is an excellent addition to our growing presence in the medical industry. It is a great strategic fit with our engineered medical components business as it provides excellent market and technology synergies. 
In addition, the business operates in markets and applications with strong growth characteristics. Laserage was privately held. It was headquartered in Waukegan, Illinois, with the manufacturing facility in Milpitas, California. 
Laserage has annual sales of $22 million. I would like to welcome the team from Laserage to AMETEK. 
We remain very active in identifying and executing highly strategic acquisitions across our businesses. The pipeline of acquisitions remains very solid, and our teams continued to do an outstanding job supporting our M&A efforts. 
In addition to our continued focus on investing in strategic acquisitions, we continue to make investments to support long-term organic growth. 
In particular, we continue to make sizable investments in research, development and engineering, and in 2016, we expect to invest $205 million or 5% of sales. I want to highlight just a few of our recent new product introductions. 
Our Solartron Analytical business, a global leader in electrochemical impedance spectroscopy for materials and electrochemical research has added 4 new application-specific instruments to their Apps-XM Series of Laboratory Instruments. The XM stands for extreme measurement and each new instrument was developed with specific capabilities for highly targeted research applications. Each occupies less than half the print -- footprint of similar laboratory instruments and provides increased measurement performance. These instruments are used for testing energy storage devices such as batteries, supercapacitors and fuel cells as well as for testing materials used in photovoltaic and solar cell applications. 
AMETEK's Aerospace & Defense developed a patent pending Exhaust Gas Thermocouple with a sheet made from an advanced and ceramic matrix composite. The Thermocouple is used to measure temperature in jet engine exhaust gases, and its highly advanced ceramic matrix heating extends the thermocouple's high temperature performance range. The heating material is 1/3 a stent of steel and nickel alloys, exhibits better performance than pure ceramic materials and extends the life of a thermocouple doubling to postpone costly jet engine overhauls. 
Our Vision Research business, which is the leader in high-speed imaging systems, unveiled its new family of Phantom VIO high-speed cameras. These compact rugged cameras are designed for a wide range of applications, including scientific analysis, material testing and defense research. The VIO family includes 8 individual models across 4 performance levels and 2 body styles providing users the flexibility for their specific needs. These high-speed high-resolution cameras are packed full of features in a 5-inch tube that is designed for durability and could stand up to 100Gs of force.
These investments in research and development combined with our strong engineering talent across the company are driving excellent new product development results. 
Revenue from new products introduced over the last 3 years, our vitality index was an excellent 25% in the quarter. 
We also remain focused on driving our Operational Excellence strategy. Our teams are doing an excellent job driving continued operational improvements through their businesses by leveraging our Operational Excellence tool-kit. 
Overall in 2016, we expect to generate $130 million in total Operational Excellence savings. These Operational Excellence activities include lean manufacturing, global sourcing and strategic procurement, value analysis and value engineering, design for Six Sigma and the movement of production to low cost locales. These OPEX initiatives also includes various tools that are focused on the front-end of our business. As I noted last quarter, we are focused on leveraging and broadening tools in this area across all of our businesses to ensure we are properly positioned for long-term growth. 
Now I'll return to the outlook for the balance of the year. Our expectations remain unchanged for the year. We continue to expect 2016 revenue to be down low single digits on a percentage basis from 2015 with organic sales down mid-single-digits. We have tightened our guidance range for 2016 to a range of approximately $2.29 to $2.31 per diluted share, leaving the midpoint of the guidance unchanged at $2.30. 
Fourth quarter 2016 sales are expected to be down low single digits versus the fourth quarter of 2015, with earnings of approximately $0.57 to $0.59 per diluted share. 
In summary, we delivered results that were in line with our expectations. We have reaffirmed our full year sales guidance and the midpoint of our earnings guidance. We have acquired 5 high-quality businesses in 2016 and our pipeline of acquisition opportunities is excellent. We generate strong free cash flow and has the balance sheet flexibility to continue to acquire great businesses. We remain focused on aggressively managing our businesses in the short term while ensuring we make appropriate investments to properly position us for 2017 and beyond. We have a deep and talented management team that will continue to execute our 4 growth strategies. 
I'm very bullish on the future of AMETEK and believe we all are well positioned to drive meaningful earnings growth and shareholder returns moving forward. 
Bill Burke will now cover some of the financial details and provide more information on our private placement. Then, we will be glad to take your questions. Bill?

headline: Ametek Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dave. As Dave noted, our business has performed well in the third quarter, with solid results that met our expectations. I'll provide some of the financial highlights. In the quarter, organic selling expenses were down roughly in line with or
componenttext:
Thank you, Dave. As Dave noted, our business has performed well in the third quarter, with solid results that met our expectations. I'll provide some of the financial highlights. 
In the quarter, organic selling expenses were down roughly in line with organic sales on a percentage basis. General and administrative expenses were up over last year's third quarter on higher consultant costs. The effective tax rate for the quarter was 25%, down from last year's rate of 26.1%. We continue to expect our tax rate for 2016 to be between 26% and 27%. As we've said before, actual quarterly tax rates can differ dramatically, either positively or negatively from this full year rate. 
Working capital defined as receivables plus inventory less payables, was 20.8% of sales in the third quarter. Capital expenditures were $15 million for the quarter, and we expect full year capital expenditures to be approximately $70 million. 
Depreciation and amortization expense in the quarter was $42 million, and for the full year, we expect depreciation and amortization to be approximately $165 million. 
Operating cash flow was $169 million in the quarter, and free cash flow was $154 million, representing 118% of net income. For the full year, we expect free cash flow to be strong 125% of net income. 
We've been very active deploying our free cash flow this year. In the third quarter, we deployed approximately $65 million on the acquisitions of NU Instruments and HS Foils, and subsequent to the end of the quarter, we deployed approximately $32 million on the acquisition of Laserage. 
These acquisitions from our cumulative expenditures for acquisitions in 2016 to approximately $390 million. 
In addition, during the third quarter, we repurchased 2.2 million shares of our stock for approximately $100 million. 
The highest priority for our cash flow remains acquisitions. However, as we have shown, we will look to opportunistically deploy our cash flow on share buybacks. 
Total debt at September 30 was $2.15 billion, up approximately $200 million from the 2015 year-end. 
Offsetting this debt is cash and cash equivalents of $445 million, resulting in a net debt to capital ratio at September 30 of 34%. 
At September 30, we had approximately $1 billion of cash and credit facilities to fund our growth initiatives. 
As we announced this morning, we entered into a private placement on October 31 to sell the equivalent of approximately $825 million in senior notes. We are issuing EUR 500 million and GBP 225 million, all with maturities ranging from 10 to 15 years. The proceeds of this offering will be used to pay down our revolver balance and to repay a GBP 40 million note due later this month. 
The private placement was well received by our lenders. Overall, decision once had a weighted average interest rate of 1.82% and a weighted average maturity of 11.5 years. This offering provides AMETEK with a larger financing capacity and increased flexibility to support our growth initiatives. 
In summary, our business is managed very well in the third quarter in the face of challenging market conditions. We remain active in deploying capital and are well positioned to support our growth initiatives with our strong balance sheet and cash flows. Kevin?
